chunks.title: Short title, extent, commencement and application
chunks.summary: This Act extends to India and specifies its applicability. It comes into force immediately and applies to companies incorporated under this Act or any other special act, insurance companies, banking companies, electricity companies, and certain bodies corporate as specified by the Central Government. The provisions of this Act override earlier laws related to companies.

chunks.title: abridged prospectus
chunks.text:
( 1 ) “abridged prospectus” means a memorandum containing such salient features of a prospectus as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board by making regulations in this behalf;

( 1 ) “abridged prospectus” means a memorandum containing such salient features of a prospectus as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board by making regulations in this behalf;
chunks.summary: The abridged prospectus refers to a summary version containing essential details specified by the Securities and Exchange Board for a prospectus. This document emphasizes salient features without including all provisions detailed in a full prospectus.

chunks.title: Formation of company
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: One Person Company (OPC) is a unique type of private company where only one individual can hold the shares. To form an OPC, seven or more persons must agree, and it requires subscription to a memorandum of association for registration in accordance with this Act. Key points include shareholder consent, written notification upon death or incapacity of another person, ability to change the name without withdrawing prior consent, and right to alter MOA/AAO as needed.

chunks.title: Formation of company - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) A may be formed for any lawful purpose by—
chunks.summary: A corporation may be formed for any lawful purpose as long as it complies with specific requirements and adheres to legal implications.

chunks.title: Formation of company - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) seven or more persons, where the company to be formed is to be a ;
chunks.summary: The incorporation process for a company involves forming seven or more persons and establishing it as an entity. The key requirements include drafting formal documents like Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA), which outline the company's rules and structure. These documents must be registered with relevant authorities to ensure legal compliance. Commencing business operations requires adhering to specific regulations, including raising capital through securities or deposits for initial share issuance.

chunks.title: Formation of company - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) two or more persons, where the company to be formed is to be a ; or
chunks.summary: The text discusses the process and requirements for forming a company that may include more than one person. Key provisions cover formation as either a limited liability or unlimited liability entity. The summary should be concise yet comprehensive, including details on how multiple persons are involved in the establishment of the new company.

chunks.title: Formation of company - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) , where the company to be formed is to be that is to say, a private company, by subscribing their names or his name to a and complying with the requirements of this Act in respect of registration: that the memorandum of One Person Company shall indicate the name of the other person, with his prior written consent in the , who shall, in the event of the subscriber’s death or his incapacity to contract become the of the company and the written consent of such person shall also be filed the at the time of incorporation of the One Person Company along with its memorandum and articles: Provided further that such other person may withdraw his consent in such manner as may be : Provided also that the member of One Person Company may at any time change the name of such other person by giving notice in such manner as may be : Provided also that it shall be the duty of the member of One Person Company to intimate the company the change, if any, in the name of the other person nominated by him by indicating in the memorandum or otherwise within such time and in such manner , and the company shall intimate the Registrar any such change within such time and in such manner as may be : Provided also that any such change in the name of the person shall not be deemed to be an of the memorandum. (2) A company formed under sub-section ( 1 ) may be either—
chunks.summary: The document outlines the regulations for One Person Companies (OPCs). A person may form a OPC by subscribing to it and complying with Act requirements. The memorandum must include the name of the other subscriber or partner who, upon death or incapacity, becomes a legal representative. This individual's consent is required initially but can be withdrawn. Members may change names within their memorandum without formal approval provided they notify the company promptly. Any such changes will not invalidate the original memorandum.

It covers essential details such as incorporation requirements, constitutional documents, business commencement, share capital management, securities issuance, charges registration, and member rights.

chunks.text: (c) an . that a Specified IFSC public company shall be formed only as a company limited by shares. that a Specified IFSC private company shall be formed only as a company limited by shares Sec. 3A If at any time the number of members of a company is reduced, in the case of a public company, below seven, in the case of a private company, below two, and the company carries on business for more than six months while the number of members is so reduced, every person who is a member of the company during the time that it so carries on business after those six months and is cognisant of the fact that it is carrying on business with less than seven members or two members, as the case may be, shall be severally liable for the payment of the whole debts of the company contracted during that time, and may be severally sued therefor. 2 (20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law 2(71) Public Company , means a company which—
chunks.summary: The text discusses a law related to the formation and operation of companies in India. It specifies that public and private companies must be formed as limited liability entities (limited by shares). There is also an obligation for former members, who are cognizant of the company's reduced membership during its extended business period, to bear the financial responsibility of any debts incurred after their exit from the company.

chunks.summary: This section defines what constitutes a 'private company' and discusses how such companies can remain public under certain conditions. A private company must meet the minimum paid-up share capital requirement as specified, but is considered public if it complies with these requirements even when owned by another public company.

If at any time the number of members of a company is reduced, in the case of a public company, below seven, in the case of a private company, below two, and the company carries on business for more than six months while the number of members is so reduced, every person who is a member of the company during the time that it so carries on business after those six months and is cognisant of the fact that it is carrying on business with less than seven members or two members, as the case may be, shall be severally liable for the payment of the whole debts of the company contracted during that time, and may be severally sued therefor.

It specifies that a Specified IFSC company must be formed as a limited liability company with shares. For both types of companies, reducing membership below the specified number results in a period during which members are liable for the debts contracted after their reduction and the six-month window is maintained beyond this point.

chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of association (MOA & AOA) are essential documents for a company's formation. Upon registration, members are automatically included in the register, and shareholders hold shares that may be beneficially owned by others. The registrar has duties under this act to register companies and handle various functions. There have been updates and revisions to regulations related to these documents, including modifications to Form INC-4 and the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017.

chunks.title: Memorandum
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions for companies registered under the Companies Act, including details about their names and objects. It specifies that if a company is a Specified IFSC, its name must include 'International Financial Service Company' or 'IFSC'. The text also outlines the requirements for incorporation of these types of companies. For compliance purposes, this seems to be related to preliminary and applicability.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) The of a shall state—
chunks.summary: The 'Of A' refers to a key provision that sets forth the conditions or requirements applicable to an entity. This includes details on the status of the entity and any necessary declarations.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) the name of the company with the last word in the case of a public limited company, or the last words in the case of a private limited company: Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a company registered under section 8; a Specified IFSC public company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name. that a Specified IFSC private company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name
chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions related to the naming conventions for companies registered in India. It specifies that public and private limited companies must include the suffix 'International Financial Service Company' or 'IFSC' in their names according to specific sections of Indian law, including certain exemptions.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the State in which the registered office of the company is to be situated;
chunks.summary: This text specifies that the registered office of a company must be located within the state where the registration process takes place. This requirement is significant for compliance with legal regulations and ensures proper jurisdiction in various administrative matters related to the business operations.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) the objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof; a Specified IFSC shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 (28 of 2005) read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India. a Specified IFSC private company shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.
chunks.summary: The document details the requirements for establishing a Specified International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) company in India. The company must state its objects to engage in financial services activities as permitted under specific acts and rules governing Special Economic Zones, obtaining necessary licenses from authorized regulatory bodies. Both types of IFSC companies need to follow these guidelines.
keywords: Securities and Exchange Board of India
Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause d
chunks.text: (d) the liability of of the company, whether limited or unlimited, and also state,—
chunks.summary: The text discusses various legal implications for companies based on their liability and state. The key provisions include limited or unlimited liability, and detailed requirements regarding company incorporation, name, registered office, conversion of companies, commencement of business, share capital, issuance and allotment of securities, acceptance of deposits, charges registration, membership rights, and more.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) in the case of a , that liability of its members is limited to the amount unpaid, if any, on the held by them; and ( ii ) in the case of a , the amount up to which each member undertakes to contribute— ( A ) to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound-up while he is a member or within one year after he ceases to be a member, for payment of the debts and liabilities of the company or of such debts and liabilities as may have been contracted before he ceases to be a member, as the case may be; and ( B ) to the costs, charges and expenses of winding-up and for adjustment of the rights of the contributories among themselves;
chunks.summary: This legal text outlines specific provisions related to the liability and contribution requirements for members in a company. It clarifies that in the event of winding-up or within one year after ceasing to be a member, each member is required to contribute up to their share of assets towards settling debts and prior liabilities. The amount applicable depends on whether they were members during the period or before their membership ended.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause e
chunks.text: (e) in the case of a company having a share capital,—
chunks.summary: When a company has share capital, it must comply with certain requirements and register the necessary documents. The company is required to have a registered office and name that matches those in its memorandum and articles of association (MOA & AOA). Shareholders can transfer shares but cannot buy back their own stock without approval from all shareholders or an agreement among them. Companies also need to file prospectuses for significant capital raising activities.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the amount of share capital with which the company is to be registered and the division thereof into shares of a fixed amount and the number of shares which the subscribers to the memorandum agree to subscribe which shall not be less than one share; and ( ii ) the number of shares each subscriber to the memorandum intends to take, indicated opposite his name;
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of association (MOA/AAO) must be approved by shareholders prior to registration. It specifies the share capital structure with fixed amounts and determines the number of shares subscribed by each shareholder, including those agreeing not to subscribe more than one share.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause f
chunks.text: (f) in the case of , the name of the person who in the event of death of the subscriber shall become the member of the company. (2) The name stated in the memorandum shall not—
chunks.summary: The person designated in the memorandum to take on the subscriber's role upon their death will become a member of the company. This name must be stated in the memorandum and cannot be altered.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) be identical with or resemble too nearly to the name of an existing company registered under this Act or any ; or
chunks.summary: The text specifies that a new company cannot have a name that is too similar to another existing registered company under this Act or any. This restriction ensures legal distinctiveness and prevents confusion among investors.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) be such that its use by the company—
chunks.summary: The company must ensure that its internal practices and policies are designed to comply with all relevant legal requirements. This includes establishing clear guidelines for decision-making processes, maintaining accurate financial records, adhering to ethical business conduct standards, and ensuring transparency in communications with stakeholders.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i

chunks.summary: The company shall not be registered with a name that contains words or symbols that may cause confusion with existing or similar companies. This restriction applies to the proposed name and ensures clear identification.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) any word or expression which is likely to give the impression that the company is in any way connected with, or having the patronage of, the Central Government, any State Government, or any local authority, corporation or body constituted by the Central Government or any State Government under any law for the time being in force; or
chunks.summary: The text specifies that any word or expression used to suggest a connection with the Central Government, State Governments, or local authorities must not be misleading. It includes provisions for companies' incorporation and name registration, as well as compliance requirements related to securities issuance, share capital, and other financial matters.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) such word or expression, as may be unless the previous approval of the Central Government has been obtained for the use of any such word or expression. (4) A person may make an application, in such and accompanied by , to the for the reservation of a name set out in the application as—
chunks.summary: The provision allows for the reservation of a name only after obtaining approval from the Central Government. An application can be made to reserve a name set out in the application, accompanied by the necessary details.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) the name of the proposed company; or
chunks.summary: This proposal outlines a new company establishment with specific details including its name and initial incorporation requirements. Compliance areas such as Company Incorporation and Constitutional Documents (MOA & AOA) are crucial for ensuring legal validity.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the name to which the company proposes to change its name. (5)
chunks.summary: The company proposes to change its name by adopting a new name. The key provisions and requirements involve ensuring that the proposed name complies with relevant laws and regulations, adhering to shareholder approvals, and maintaining continuity in corporate identity. This change will likely impact the registered office address and possibly other legal documents such as the memorandum of association (MOA) or articles of association (AOA). It also necessitates updating the prospectus for public offerings if applicable, ensuring compliance with all securities regulations.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and documents furnished along with the application, reserve the name for a period of sixty day from the date of the application. This implies an oversight or misapplication of legal procedures regarding company names in unincorporated entities.

chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository 2(22) Company limited by shares means a company having the liability of its members limited by the memorandum to the amount, if any, unpaid on the shares respectively held by them 2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock 2(21) Company limited by guarantee means a company having the liability of its members limited by the memorandum to such amount as the members may respectively undertake to contribute to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound up 2(62) One Person Company means a company which has only one person as a member 2(67) Previous company law means any of the laws specified below: —
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of association (MOA and AOA) set forth the fundamental principles for establishing and operating a company. Key provisions include who qualifies as a member or shareholder based on written agreements and how changes in names, addresses, or shareholdings are recorded. The MOA also specifies liability limits, defining what constitutes a beneficial owner.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) Acts relating to companies in force before the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( ii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( iii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1882 (6 of 1882); ( iv ) the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913);
chunks.summary: These provisions cover key areas in Indian company law such as pre-1866 statutes (i), the 1866 Act (ii), and subsequent modifications like the 1882 and 1913 Acts (iii, iv). They include requirements for incorporation, names, registered offices, share capital structure, issue of securities, prospectuses, allotment, transfer, buy-back, deposits, charges registration, members' rights, beneficial ownership, and voting. The summary highlights the continuity and evolution of company law in India.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) The of a shall state—

( a )  the name of the company with the last word in the case of a public limited company, or the last words in the case of a private limited company:

Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a company registered under section 8;

a Specified IFSC public company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name.

that a Specified IFSC private company shall have the suffix “International Financial Service Company” or “IFSC” as part of its name

( b ) the State in which the registered office of the company is to be situated;

( c ) the objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof;

a Specified IFSC shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 (28 of 2005) read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.

a Specified IFSC private company shall state its objects to do financial services activities, as permitted under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006 and any matter considered necessary in furtherance thereof, in accordance with license to operate, from International Financial Services Centre located in an approved multi services Special Economic Zone, granted by the Reserve Bank of India or the Securities and Exchange Board of India or the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India.

( d ) the liability of of the company, whether limited or unlimited, and also state,—

( i ) in the case of a , that liability of its members is limited to the amount unpaid, if any, on the held by them; and

( ii ) in the case of a , the amount up to which each member undertakes to contribute—

( A ) to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound-up while he is a member or within one year after he ceases to be a member, for payment of the debts and liabilities of the company or of such debts and liabilities as may have been contracted before he ceases to be a member, as the case may be; and

( B ) to the costs, charges and expenses of winding-up and for adjustment of the rights of the contributories among themselves;

( e ) in the case of a company having a share capital,—

( i ) the amount of share capital with which the company is to be registered and the division thereof into shares of a fixed amount and the number of shares which the subscribers to the memorandum agree to subscribe which shall not be less than one share; and

( ii ) the number of shares each subscriber to the memorandum intends to take, indicated opposite his name;

( f ) in the case of , the name of the person who in the event of death of the subscriber shall become the member of the company.
chunks.summary: The summary is required to cover key provisions related to a company's incorporation and registration under specified regulations, including its name, objects, liability, capital structure, and more. The compliance area relevant would be 'Company Incorporation' as it pertains to the initial formation of the company.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) The name stated in the memorandum shall not—

( a ) be identical with or resemble too nearly to the name of an existing company registered under this Act or any ; or

( b ) be such that its use by the company—

( i ) will constitute an offence under any law for the time being in force; or

( ii ) is in the opinion of the,
chunks.summary: A memorandum must have a unique name that does not resemble another company's registered name or be subject to legal prohibitions. Additionally, it should ensure compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 3
chunks.text:
(3) Without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), a company shall not be registered with a name which contains—

( a ) any word or expression which is likely to give the impression that the company is in any way connected with, or having the patronage of, the Central Government, any State Government, or any local authority, corporation or body constituted by the Central Government or any State Government under any law for the time being in force; or

( b ) such word or expression, as may be

unless the previous approval of the Central Government has been obtained for the use of any such word or expression.
chunks.summary: A company must not use a name that suggests it is associated with any government body or corporation. The registration application should also obtain approval for any potentially infringing words.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 4
chunks.text:
(4) A person may make an application, in such and accompanied by , to the for the reservation of a name set out in the application as—

( a ) the name of the proposed company; or

( b ) the name to which the company proposes to change its name.
chunks.summary: The applicant can submit an application to reserve a specified name either as the proposed company's name or the name that the company plans to change.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 5
chunks.text:
(5) ( i ) Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and documents furnished along with the application, reserve the name for a period of sixty day from the date of the application.

Upon receipt of an application under sub-section (4), the Registrar may, on the basis of information and furnished along with the application, the name for a period of twenty days from the date of approval or such other period as may be prescribed:

Provided that in case of an application for reservation of name or for change of its name by an existing company, the Registrar may reserve the name for a period of sixty days from the date of approval.

( ii ) Where after reservation of name under clause ( i ), it is found that name was applied by furnishing wrong or incorrect information, then,—

( a ) if the company has not been incorporated, the reserved name shall be cancelled and the person making application under sub-section (4) shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to one lakh rupees;

( b ) if the company has been incorporated, the Registrar may, after giving the company an opportunity of being heard—

( i ) either direct the company to change its name within a period of three months, after passing an ordinary resolution;

( ii ) take action for striking off the name of the company from the ; or

( iii ) make a petition for winding up of the company.
chunks.summary: The legal text outlines provisions for the reservation and modification of company names by a Registrar. Upon approval, companies can have their names reserved or changed within specified timeframes based on accuracy of information provided. For reservations without incorporation, failure to provide correct information results in cancellation of the name with penalties. In cases involving existing companies, further actions are available including rectification, striking off from registration, and winding up.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 6
chunks.text: (6) The memorandum of a company shall be in respective forms specified in Tables A, B, C, D and E in as may be applicable to such company.
chunks.summary: The memorandum of a company must be in specified forms applicable to the type of company. This ensures uniformity and clarity regarding the document's structure.

This applies irrespective of whether the subsidiary continues as a private company in its articles, enhancing the operational flexibility and potential market access options for such subsidiaries.

chunks.summary:
The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) serve as foundational documents for a company. The subscriber or any other person who agrees to become a member through written consent must be registered in the register of members. Shares, beneficial ownership records, and deposits may also indicate membership status.

This summary covers key provisions regarding the registration of members, beneficial ownership, and the legal implications of changes related to the MOA/AOA, including the entry into voting rights.

chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of association (MOA/AOA) are legally binding documents that govern a company's operations. The memorandum sets out fundamental principles such as the liability limit for members or shareholders, while the articles detail how these rules will be implemented through share capital, securities issuance, and other operational details.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 7 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) Acts relating to companies in force before the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( ii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( iii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1882 (6 of 1882); ( iv ) the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913);
chunks.summary: This text refers to four specific acts related to companies in India, including two from before and one each from 1866, 1882, and 1913. The Indian Companies Act of 1866 (10 of 1866) forms the foundation, followed by a significant update in 1882 (6 of 1882), another change in 1913 (7 of 1913). The documents cover various aspects such as company incorporation, constitutional documents, registered office and name, commencement of business, share capital, securities issuance, prospectus and capital raising, allotment and transfer of securities, buy-back of securities, acceptance of deposits, charges registration, members' rights, beneficial ownership, and the register of members. These acts establish standards for corporate governance, including compliance with statutory requirements, maintaining clear records of company actions, and ensuring proper management of assets.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 7 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) the Registration of Transferred Companies Ordinance, 1942 (Ord. 54 of 1942); ( vi ) the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956); and ( vii ) any law corresponding to any of the aforesaid Acts or the Ordinances and in force— ( A ) in the merged territories or in a Part B State (other than the State of Jammu and Kashmir), or any part thereof, before the extension thereto of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913); or ( B ) in the State of Jammu and Kashmir, or any part thereof, before the commencement of the Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act, 1956 (62 of 1956), in so far as banking, insurance and financial corporations are concerned, and before the commencement of the Central Laws (Extension to Jammu and Kashmir) Act, 1968 (25 of 1968), in so far as other corporations are concerned; ( viii ) the Portuguese Commercial Code, in so far as it relates to sociedades anonimas ; and ( ix ) the Registration of Companies (Sikkim) Act, 1961 (Sikkim Act 8 of 1961)(Not notified)
chunks.summary: The text outlines a set of laws applicable to certain companies and corporations in India. It includes references to the Registration of Transferred Companies Ordinance, the Companies Act, various Acts from merged territories and other states, as well as specific requirements for incorporation, registered offices, and matters related to share capital and securities transactions. Key provisions cover legal interpretations, corporate governance, and compliance with existing laws.

chunks.title: Memorandum - Subsection 7 Clause i

The Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866) and subsequent acts from 1882 onwards were all enacted as amendments or updates to the original act. These provisions cover aspects such as company incorporation, registration, capital structure, share issuance, and various financial transactions like allotment of securities, buy-back policies, and charges on assets.

It references various Acts and Ordinances that govern corporate entities, including requirements for companies registered before certain dates and specific jurisdictions like Jammu and Kashmir or parts thereof. The summary also mentions powers delegated to the Registrar of Companies, clarification on documents included in a register, and references to compliance areas such as Company Incorporation.

chunks.title: Articles
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: The document specifies that articles of association must include provisions for management regulations and may contain additional matters deemed necessary. Articles can be entrenchable but require specific conditions or procedures met by a resolution. Entrenched provisions apply only during company formation, amendments agreed to by all members, or special resolutions.

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) The of a shall contain the regulations for management of the company. (2) The articles shall also contain such matters, as may be : Provided that nothing prescribed in this sub-section shall be deemed to prevent a company from including such additional matters in its articles as may be considered necessary for its management. (3) The articles may contain provisions for entrenchment to the effect that specified provisions of the articles may be only if conditions or procedures as that are more restrictive than those applicable in the case of a special resolution, are met or complied with. (4) The provisions for entrenchment referred to in sub-section (3) shall only be made either on formation of a company, or by an amendment in the articles agreed to by all the of the company in the case of a and by a special resolution in the case of a . (5) Where the articles contain provisions for entrenchment, whether made on formation or by amendment, the company shall give notice to the Registrar of such provisions in such as may be . (6) The articles of a company shall be in respective forms specified in Tables G, I and J in as may be applicable to such company. (7) A company may adopt all or any of the regulations contained in the model articles applicable to such company. (8) In case of any company, which is registered after the commencement of this Act, in so far as the registered articles of such company do not exclude or modify the regulations contained in the model articles applicable to such company, those regulations shall, so far as applicable, be the regulations of that company in the same manner and to the extent as if they were contained in the duly registered articles of the company. (9) Nothing in this section shall apply to the articles of a company registered under any unless amended under this Act. Articles means the articles of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law Refer rule 11 of The Companies (Incorporation) Rules, 2014. To view the rule, Click Here alter includes the making of additions, omissions and substitutions. 2(55) Member , in relation to a company, means—
chunks.summary: Article and by-laws (1) - (8): This text outlines various provisions related to articles and by-laws in a company. It mentions that these documents should contain specific regulations for management purposes. The document also specifies that certain matters can be included based on necessity, while prohibiting any additional restrictions unless conditions or special resolutions are met. Articles may include entrenchment provisions that must comply with stricter conditions than those required for a general resolution and must be either adopted during formation or as an amendment agreed upon by all shareholders in the case of a public company. The documents require specific notice to the Registrar when included. Articles of incorporation, which originally framed, shall not exclude regulations applicable under this Act unless amended according to the provisions stated.

The legal implication is that companies may tailor their articles based on operational requirements without being restricted by the initial prescribed items.

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 3

For certain types of amendments and special resolutions, they apply only if approved by an additional vote.

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 5

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 6

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 7

chunks.title: Articles - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) In case of any company, which is registered after the commencement of this Act, in so far as the registered articles of such company do not exclude or modify the regulations contained in the model articles applicable to such company, those regulations shall, so far as applicable, be the regulations of that company in the same manner and to the extent as if they were contained in the duly registered articles of the company.
chunks.summary: The text states that if a company registers after this Act's commencement, its registered articles shall follow the applicable model articles to the same extent as they would in an existing company with validly filed articles. chunks.title: Act to over-ride memorandum, articles, etc.
chunks.text:
Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act— ( a ) the provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the or of a , or in any agreement executed by it, or in any resolution passed by the company in general meeting or by its , whether the same be registered, executed or passed, as the case may be, before or after the commencement of this Act; and ( b ) any provision contained in the memorandum, articles, agreement or resolution shall, to the extent to which it is repugnant to the provisions of this Act, become or be void, as the case may be. 2(56) Memorandum means the memorandum of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act Articles means the articles of association of a  Company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law Board of Directors , in relation to a company, means the collective body of the directors of the company

Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act—

( a ) the provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the or of a , or in any agreement executed by it, or in any resolution passed by the company in general meeting or by its , whether the same be registered, executed or passed, as the case may be, before or after the commencement of this Act; and

( b ) any provision contained in the memorandum, articles, agreement or resolution shall, to the extent to which it is repugnant to the provisions of this Act, become or be void, as the case may be.

2(56) Memorandum means the memorandum of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act

Articles means the articles of association of a  Company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act

Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

Board of Directors , in relation to a company, means the collective body of the directors of the company
chunks.summary: This Act is effective notwithstanding any contrary provisions found in memorandum, articles, agreements or resolutions. The scope of this Act’s applicability extends to all company-related documents and actions executed prior to its commencement. Any conflicting provisions within these documents will be deemed void unless expressly provided otherwise.

chunks.text: (i) Acts relating to companies in force before the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( ii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( iii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1882 (6 of 1882); ( iv ) the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913);
chunks.summary: The text covers four primary acts related to companies in India with varying historical context and impact. The Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866) is foundational, followed by its subsequent amendments including the 1913 act. These laws provide comprehensive rules for company formation, operations, and management.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) the Registration of Transferred Companies Ordinance, 1942 (Ord. 54 of 1942); ( vi ) the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956); and ( vii ) any law corresponding to any of the aforesaid Acts or the Ordinances and in force— ( A ) in the merged territories or in a Part B State (other than the State of Jammu and Kashmir), or any part thereof, before the extension thereto of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913); or ( B ) in the State of Jammu and Kashmir, or any part thereof, before the commencement of the Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act, 1956 (62 of 1956), in so far as banking, insurance and financial corporations are concerned, and before the commencement of the Central Laws (Extension to Jammu and Kashmir) Act, 1968 (25 of 1968), in so far as other corporations are concerned; ( viii ) the Portuguese Commercial Code, in so far as it relates to sociedades anonimas ; and ( ix ) the Registration of Companies (Sikkim) Act, 1961 (Sikkim Act 8 of 1961)(Not notified) 2(36) Document includes summons, notice, requisition, order, declaration, form and register, whether issued, sent or kept in pursuance of this Act or under any other law for the time being in force or otherwise, maintained on paper or in electronic form 2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act 2(11) Body Corporate includes a company incorporated outside India, but does not include—
chunks.summary: The document discusses the various provisions related to the registration and incorporation of companies in India. It mentions the relevant laws such as the Companies Act, 1956 (1956), Indian Companies Act, 1913 (1913), Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act, 1956 (1956), Central Laws (Extension to Jammu and Kashmir) Act, 1968 (1968), Portuguese Commercial Code, Sikkim Registration of Companies Act, 1961 (Sikkim Act 8 of 1961), as well as the Registration of Transferred Companies Ordinance, 1942. It specifies that these laws apply only to certain territories or states in India and Jammu and Kashmir respectively before specific dates and acts were extended. The document also mentions various provisions related to company registration, incorporation, conversion, business commencement, share capital, securities, charges, members, beneficial ownership, etc.

chunks.summary: This provision applies to entities identified by a company in its annual return or through a prospectus. The key provisions involve identifying specific persons with significant interest and rights over the entity's capital structure.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) who has control over the affairs of the company, directly or indirectly whether as a shareholder, director or otherwise; or
chunks.summary: This provision outlines that the person or entity having control over a company's affairs can be either directly or indirectly through being a shareholder, director, or any other form. This control extends to making decisions on behalf of the company and includes its internal operations as well as dealings outside the corporate structure.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository 2(74) Register of companies means the register of companies maintained by the Registrar on paper or in any electronic mode under this Act To view the notification, Click Here To view the notification, Click Here vide notification S.O 1934(E). To view the notification, Click Here
chunks.summary:
The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) serve as fundamental documents for a company, defining its structure, purpose, and operational rules. Upon registration, members are officially acknowledged, and their names are entered in the register of members. Shareholders with shares held in a depository are also registered under the terms of this document.

Key provisions include:
- The MOA and AOA outline company governance and operations.
- Members can be anyone agreeing to become part through written agreements.
- Beneficial ownership is tracked for shareholders holding securities.

Compliance area: Company Incorporation and Constitutional Documents (MOA & AOA).

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 1
chunks.summary: The registration of a company must include signatures from subscribers, compliance with Act and rules, declarations by individuals meeting specific criteria, information about subscribers, directors' convictions, registered office address, subscriber details including proof of identity, and directors' particulars.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) The Registrar on the basis of documents and information filed under sub-section (1) shall register all the documents and information referred to in that sub-section in the register and issue a certificate of incorporation in the to the effect that the proposed company is incorporated under this Act.
chunks.summary: The Registrar registers documents and information filed under Section (1) to establish a company. This includes issuing a certificate of incorporation. Key provisions ensure accurate records and formal approval.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 3
chunks.text: (3) On and from the date mentioned in the certificate of incorporation issued under sub-section (2), the Registrar shall allot to the company a corporate identity number, which shall be a distinct identity for the company and which shall also be included in the certificate.
chunks.summary: The text outlines that after issuance of a certificate of incorporation under sub-section (2), the registrar must allocate to the company a corporate identity number. This number is distinct and part of the company's certificate and should also appear in it.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) The company shall maintain and preserve at its registered office copies of all documents and information as originally filed under sub-section (1) till its dissolution under this Act.
chunks.summary: The company must keep copies of all documents and information filed under Sub-section (1) until its dissolution. This ensures compliance with legal preservation requirements.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 5
chunks.text: (5) If any person furnishes any false or incorrect particulars of any information or suppresses any material information, of which he is aware in any of the documents filed with the Registrar in relation to the registration of a company, he shall be liable for action under section 447.
chunks.summary: The text outlines that anyone furnishing false or incorrect information in documents filed with a registrar for the registration of a company is liable under section 447. This applies specifically to any details related to a company.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 6
chunks.text: (6) Without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (5) where, at any time after the incorporation of a company, it is proved that the company has been got incorporated by furnishing any false or incorrect information or representation or by suppressing any material fact or information in any of the documents or declaration filed or made for incorporating such company, or by any fraudulent action, the , the persons named as the first directors of the company and the persons making declaration under clause ( b ) of sub-section (1) shall each be liable for action under section 447.
chunks.summary: If a company is incorporated through false or incorrect information or representations, or if it suppresses material facts or falsifies documents filed for incorporation, the first directors and those making declarations under clause (b) of sub-section (1) are liable under section 447.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 7 Clause 1
chunks.text: (7) Without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (6), where a company has been got incorporated by furnishing any false or incorrect information or representation or by suppressing any material fact or information in any of the documents or declaration filed or made for incorporating such company or by any fraudulent action, the may, on an made to it, on being satisfied that the situation so warrants,—
chunks.summary: Incorporating a company requires furnishing accurate information and documents. False or incorrect filings can lead to non-incorporation or suspension of operations by an authority if deemed warranted.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 7 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) pass such orders, as it may think fit, for regulation of the management of the company including changes, if any, in its memorandum and articles, in public interest or in the interest of the company and its and creditors; or
chunks.summary: This provision allows a company to amend its memorandum and articles as it deems necessary in public interest or for the benefit of the company and creditors. This can include changes related to management, which may include alterations to the shareholders' rights and duties.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 7 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) direct that liability of the members shall be unlimited; or
chunks.summary: The text describes provisions related to unlimited liability for company members and the conditions under which such liability may apply. This includes specific rules regarding shareholders' rights, obligations, and how they are affected by the incorporation of a company.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 7 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) direct removal of the name of the company from the ; or
chunks.summary: The company's name must either be directly removed from the registered office or the memorandum and articles. This ensures that the company maintains a valid legal existence.

chunks.title: Incorporation of company - Subsection 7 Clause d
chunks.text: (d) pass an order for the winding up of the company; or
chunks.summary: The text outlines provisions related to a company's dissolution. It mentions that an order for winding up can be passed by the company itself or through a court order when certain conditions are met, such as not being able to pay its debts as they come due.

Provided that before making any order under this sub-section,—
chunks.summary: The order may include provisions for modifying or changing the Memorandum and Articles (MOA and AOA) based on certain circumstances, but requires prior notice to the members and stakeholders.

chunks.summary: The summary covers key provisions and requirements from various Indian Companies Acts dating back to 1866. The text includes references to prior legislation (Act 10 of 1866), a foundational act (Act 10 of 1866 itself), an updated act in 1882 (Act 6 of 1882), and a significant revision in 1913 (Act 7 of 1913). The acts address company incorporation, constitutional documents, registered office and name, conversion, commencement of business, share capital, securities issuance, prospectus registration, allotment and transfer of securities, buy-back, deposit acceptance, charges registration, member rights, and beneficial ownership.

chunks.summary: The Legal Framework for Company Incorporation and Registration in India provides a detailed overview of the requirements and procedures involved in incorporating a company under the Companies Act, 2013. The rule-based system includes specific provisions such as promoter definition, return viewing, amendment of memorandum and articles, registered office address, conversion from other legal entities, commencement of business, share capital, securities issuance, prospectus and capital raising, allotment of shares, transfer of securities, buy-back policies, deposits acceptance, charges registration, members' rights, beneficial ownership tracking, and the register of members. The key compliance areas encompass preliminary provisions, company incorporation details, constitutional documents, registered office requirements, effect on existing memorandum and articles, conversion processes, commencement of business rules, share capital management, securities issuance regulations, prospectus guidelines, charge registrations, member rights protection, and detailed registration requirements.

chunks.summary:
The memorandum of association (MOA) is the foundational document that outlines the essential conditions for a company's existence. Once registered, members must be identified and their names entered in the register of companies. This includes subscribers to the MOA, individuals who agree in writing to become members but whose names are not yet entered, and beneficial owners of shares held by depositories.

The memorandum and articles of association (MOA & AOA) constitute an essential part of a company's constitutional documents. The register of companies is maintained for paper-based or electronic records under the Companies Act. The notification to view the register of companies can be accessed through specified links, indicating that viewing the register without permission may infringe on legal rights.

chunks.text: (c) of that sub-section, it may, by licence, allow the company to be registered under this section subject to such conditions as the Central Government deems fit and to change its name by omitting the word “Limited”, or as the case may be, the words “Private Limited” from its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, on application, register such company under this section and all the provisions of this section shall apply to that company. (6) The may, by order, revoke the licence granted to a company registered under this section if the company contravenes any of the requirements of this section or any of the conditions subject to which a licence is issued or the affairs of the company are conducted fraudulently or in a manner violative of the objects of the company or prejudicial to public interest, and without prejudice to any other action against the company under this Act, direct the company to convert its status and change its name to add the word “Limited” or the words “Private Limited”, as the case may be, to its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, without prejudice to any action that may be taken under sub-section (7), on application, register the company accordingly: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard: Provided further that a copy of every such order shall be given to the Registrar. (7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order. (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269. (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects. (11) If a company makes any default in complying with any of the requirements laid down in this section, the company shall, without prejudice to any other action under the provisions of this section, be punishable with fine which shall not be less than ten lakh rupees but which may extend to one crore rupees and the and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees but which may extend to twenty-five lakh rupees, or with both : Provided that when it is proved that the affairs of the company were conducted fraudulently, every officer in default shall be liable for action under section 447. a) Powers are delegated to Registrar of Companies vide notification S.O 1353(E).To view the notification, Click Here b)The Central registration center shall exercise functional jurisdiction of processing and disposal of all e-forms and related matters pertaining to registration of companies, vide notification S.O.1211(E) dated 23 March, 2016. (6) The may, by order, revoke the licence granted to a company registered under this section if the company contravenes any of the requirements of this section or any of the conditions subject to which a licence is issued or the affairs of the company are conducted fraudulently or in a manner violative of the objects of the company or prejudicial to public interest, and without prejudice to any other action against the company under this Act, direct the company to convert its status and change its name to add the word “Limited” or the words “Private Limited”, as the case may be, to its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, without prejudice to any action that may be taken under sub-section (7), on application, register the company accordingly: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard: Provided further that a copy of every such order shall be given to the Registrar. (7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order. (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269. (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects. (11) If a company makes any default in complying with any of the requirements laid down in this section, the company shall, without prejudice to any other action under the provisions of this section, be punishable with fine which shall not be less than ten lakh rupees but which may extend to one crore rupees and the and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees but which may extend to twenty-five lakh rupees, or with both : Provided that when it is proved that the affairs of the company were conducted fraudulently, every officer in default shall be liable for action under section 447. a) Powers are delegated to Registrar of Companies vide notification S.O 1353(E).To view the notification, Click Here b)The Central registration center shall exercise functional jurisdiction of processing and disposal of all e-forms and related matters pertaining to registration of companies, vide notification S.O.1211(E) dated 23 March, 2016. chunks.summary:
The document outlines regulations for companies registered under a specific section. It allows for registration with certain conditions and requirements including changing the name if necessary. The central government has the power to revoke licenses and revocation orders can lead to winding up, amalgamation, or dissolution of the company in the public interest.

Key provisions include licensing, revoking licences, winding-up, amalgamation, and conversion. Companies must comply with certain requirements without prejudice to any other legal action. There is also a provision for defaulting companies to be fined.

chunks.summary: These acts cover several aspects of Indian company law, including pre-1866 laws (I), 1866 Act (II), 1882 Act (III), and 1913 Act (IV). They provide comprehensive coverage from the inception of company formation to detailed provisions on registration, share capital, securities issues, prospectus requirements, charges, voting rights, and more. The key features include pre-legal era practices, modern statutory amendments, and regulations aimed at maintaining clarity in legal compliance.

chunks.summary: The document outlines the jurisdiction and processing requirements for registering companies under specific laws. It emphasizes the functional jurisdiction of the central registration center, supersession of notifications, delegation of powers to regional directors, and changes in certain terms related to company law. The document also specifies key provisions such as the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), amendments to the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2020, and requirements for registered office, name, conversion of companies, commencement of business, share capital, issuance of securities, etc.

It also clarifies that other individuals who agree to become members or beneficial owners through written agreement will have their names entered in the register of members. The registration process is governed by specific rules, including forms and notifications related to changes in the Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA). The registrar has the authority to alter these documents if they are altered from time to time or as per company laws.

chunks.summary:
The document outlines several key provisions related to corporate registration and compliance. It specifies that the Central Registration Center exercises functional jurisdiction for processing company registrations and incorporates laws from various jurisdictions such as the Portuguese Commercial Code, Sikkim's Registration of Companies Act, and others relevant to specific territories.

Requirements include updating rules and forms (e.g., INC 12, INC 14) in response to changes in legal regulations. Notable changes are supersession of previous notifications, delegation of powers to regional directors, amendments in regulatory bodies like the National Company Law Tribunal and Companies Amendment Act, and updates to company incorporation requirements. The document also specifies keywords such as 'regional director', 'national company law tribunal', and 'companies amendment act' for effective compliance.

chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) serve as fundamental documents for a company's constitution. The MOA outlines the purpose and organizational structure of the company, while the AOA specifies its operational rules and details on shares and their distribution among members. Registration of members and beneficial ownership is required; amendments to either document must be made in writing, and registered with the appropriate authorities. For instance, the MOA may change through notification S.O 1352 (E), affecting only specific provisions of the original memorandum.

chunks.summary: The document outlines the provisions and requirements for registering companies under various laws in India. It includes specific references to different Acts such as the Companies Act, 1956; the Portuguese Commercial Code; and the Registration of Companies (Sikkim) Act, 1961. The text also details changes made through notifications regarding the National Company Law Tribunal, Directors, Officers, and the revised Companies (Incorporation) Rules, 2014.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 6 Clause 1
chunks.text: (6) The may, by order, revoke the licence granted to a company registered under this section if the company contravenes any of the requirements of this section or any of the conditions subject to which a licence is issued or the affairs of the company are conducted fraudulently or in a manner violative of the objects of the company or prejudicial to public interest, and without prejudice to any other action against the company under this Act, direct the company to convert its status and change its name to add the word “Limited” or the words “Private Limited”, as the case may be, to its name and thereupon the Registrar shall, without prejudice to any action that may be taken under sub-section (7), on application, register the company accordingly: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard: Provided further that a copy of every such order shall be given to the Registrar. (7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section: Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard. (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order. (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269. (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects. (11) If a company makes any default in complying with any of the requirements laid down in this section, the company shall, without prejudice to any other action under the provisions of this section, be punishable with fine which shall not be less than ten lakh rupees but which may extend to one crore rupees and the and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees but which may extend to twenty-five lakh rupees, or with both : Provided that when it is proved that the affairs of the company were conducted fraudulently, every officer in default shall be liable for action under section 447. a) Powers are delegated to Registrar of Companies vide notification S.O 1353(E).To view the notification, Click Here b)The Central registration center shall exercise functional jurisdiction of processing and disposal of all e-forms and related matters pertaining to registration of companies, vide notification S.O.1211(E) dated 23 March, 2016. The key provisions include revocation of a company's license upon violation, winding up or amalgamation under public interest, and dissolution conditions for companies. It also outlines penalties for defaulting members and the transfer of remaining assets after liquidation.

Keywords: License Revocation, Winding Up, Amalgamation, Public Interest, Default, Penalties.

Upon registration with a registrar designated by the Companies Act, these documents become part of the company's public records. It also highlights compliance areas related to the act's interpretation and application.

It specifies which acts, ordinances, or corresponding laws apply under specific conditions for certain territories and states. It also provides updates on rule revisions and notifications for processing and managing e-forms of companies registered under these laws.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 7
chunks.text:
(7) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6), the Central Government may, by order, if it is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest, direct that the company be wound up under this Act or amalgamated with another company registered under this section:

Provided that no such order shall be made unless the company is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
chunks.summary: If a company's licence is revoked under Section 67(1), it may be wound up or amalgamated with another registered company in the public interest. The Central Government must give the company a reasonable opportunity to be heard before making such an order.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) Where a licence is revoked under sub-section (6) and where the Central Government is satisfied that it is essential in the public interest that the company registered under this section should be amalgamated with another company registered under this section and having similar objects, then, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Act, the Central Government may, by order, provide for such amalgamation to form a single company with such constitution, properties, powers, rights, interest, authorities and privileges and with such liabilities, duties and obligations as may be specified in the order.
chunks.summary: The Central Government may amalgamate two registered companies with similar objects if it is deemed essential in public interest. The amalgamation process requires an order specifying the new company's constitution and properties, powers, rights, interests, authorities, privileges, liabilities, duties, and obligations. This occurs under Section 136(8) of the Companies Act.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) If on the winding up or dissolution of a company registered under this section, there remains, after the satisfaction of its debts and liabilities, any asset, they may be transferred to another company registered under this section and having similar objects, subject to such conditions as the may impose, or may be sold and proceeds thereof credited to t he Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under section 269.
chunks.summary: The legal text outlines provisions for transferring remaining assets from a company registered under this section to another similar company after winding up or dissolution. Conditions and requirements are imposed by the new company, subject to conditions set by the Rehabilitation and Insolvency Fund formed under Section 269.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 10
chunks.text: (10) A company registered under this section shall amalgamate only with another company registered under this section and having similar objects.
chunks.summary: The company registered under this section may only amalgamate with another company that is also registered under this section and has similar objects. This requirement ensures uniformity in operations among companies within the same sector.

chunks.title: Formation of companies with charitable objects, etc - Subsection 11 Clause i
chunks.summary: The provided text covers four key sections related to Indian company law from different eras. The Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866) and its amendments set foundational rules for companies established before the current framework. The Indian Companies Act, 1882 (6 of 1882), introduces modern corporate governance practices. The 1913 act expands on earlier legislation with specific provisions for share capital management, securities transactions, and business commencement. These sections collectively aim to regulate company formation, operations, and shareholder rights within the Indian legal framework.
