chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) is a crucial document for incorporated companies in India that outlines the rights and obligations of shareholders. It specifies who qualifies as a member and provides details on succession, property acquisition, contract rights, and liability. The MOA can be altered or amended as per specified provisions, subject to certain exceptions.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles (MOA/AAO) bind a company to the same extent as if they were signed by both parties. All monies payable under MOA/AAO are debts due from members to the company. A new company must file a declaration within a specified period and verify its payment of shares before commencing business or borrowing powers.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, the and shall, when registered, bind the and the thereof to the same extent as if they respectively had been signed by the company and by each member, and contained covenants on its and his part to observe all the provisions of the memorandum and of the articles. (2) All monies payable by any member to the company under the memorandum or articles shall be a debt due from him to the company. (1) A company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 and having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless—
chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions regarding the binding effect of a memorandum and articles on all members of a company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019. It clarifies that when a member pays money under the memorandum or articles, it is considered as owing to the company and not a personal debt. Additionally, it outlines specific requirements for companies incorporating after this act's commencement regarding their operational scope.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) a declaration is filed by a director within a period of of the date of incorporation of the company in such form and verified in such manner as may be prescribed, with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him on the date of making of such declaration; and
chunks.summary: A declaration by a director is required within a specified period after the company's incorporation to verify that every subscriber has paid the agreed-upon share value. This ensures transparency and adherence to the memorandum of association.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12. (2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty of fifty thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be liable to a penalty of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues but not exceeding an amount of one lakh rupees. (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause
chunks.summary: The company has filed a verification of its registered office in accordance with Section 12(2). Failure to comply results in fines ranging from 50,000 rupees to one lakh rupees for both the company and individual officers. The penalties continue up to six months or until compliance is restored.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII (1) A company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018 and having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless—
chunks.summary: A company incorporated after the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018, whose share capital is greater than or equal to Rs. 50 lakh must commence any business or exercise borrowing powers within a period of one hundred and eighty days from its incorporation date unless the Registrar believes that such commencement would not be in the interest of the company's shareholders.

chunks.text: (a) a declaration is filed by a director within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company in such form and verified in such manner , with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him on the date of making of such declaration; and
chunks.summary: A director must file a declaration within one hundred and eighty days after incorporation with the Registrar. This declaration confirms that all subscribers to the memorandum have paid their agreed-upon share value on the date of filing.

chunks.summary: A company has completed its registration with a verification of its registered office. Non-compliance with this requirement can result in fines ranging from fifty thousand to one lakh rupees for both the company and any defaulting officers.

The process includes an expedited timeline of one hundred and eighty days for incorporation, followed by removal if no business is conducted. This highlights regulatory compliance requirements aimed at ensuring registered entities are operational.

chunks.summary: The amendment has provided an additional 180 days for individuals to become members of a company after its registration. It has also extended the relaxation period for certain circulars related to member eligibility and shares. The amendments are part of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019, which repeals the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, the and shall, when registered, bind the and the thereof to the same extent as if they respectively had been signed by the company and by each member, and contained covenants on its and his part to observe all the provisions of the memorandum and of the articles.
chunks.summary: This legislation ensures that company documents signed by registered members have the same binding effect as those signed directly by the company. This applies to memorandums and articles (MOA & AOA), enabling companies to include terms without having specific signatures.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) All monies payable by any member to the company under the memorandum or articles shall be a debt due from him to the company.
chunks.summary: This provision establishes that any monies owed by a company's member to the corporation are legally considered as a debt due from the individual. This highlights the legal responsibility of members towards the company and sets forth the fundamental principle of fiduciary duty.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) A company incorporated after the commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 and having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless—

(a) a declaration is filed by a director within a period of of the date of incorporation of the company in such form and verified in such manner as may be prescribed, with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him on the date of making of such declaration; and

(b) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12.
chunks.summary: A company incorporated after the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019, and having a share capital must file a declaration with the Registrar within the specified period from its incorporation. The company also needs to provide verification of its registered office through sub-section (2) of section 12 before commencing any business or exercising borrowing powers.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty of fifty thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be liable to a penalty of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues but not exceeding an amount of one lakh rupees.
chunks.summary: Failure to comply with the provisions of this section may result in penalties ranging from five thousand rupees for each default (company) to one hundred thousand rupees for each day of non-compliance. Officers who are in default face penalties ranging from one thousand rupees per default (officer) to one lakh rupees total.

chunks.title: Effect of memorandum and articles - Subsection 3
chunks.text: (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause (a) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII
chunks.summary: If a company fails to file a declaration with the Registrar within one hundred and eighty days after incorporation without reasonable cause and if the Registrar believes that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, they may initiate action for the removal of the company's name from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII.

(b) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-­section (2) of section 12.

It also needs to verify that every subscriber has paid their agreed share value as per the memorandum of association. Additionally, the company must register its registered office for verification.

It specifies that if a company has not filed a declaration under Clause (a) of Sub-section (1) within one hundred and eighty days from incorporation and there is reasonable cause to believe the company is not operating, the Registrar can remove its name from the register without prejudice to section 2(56). chunks.title: Commencement of business, etc. -Omitted
chunks.text:
(1) A having a share capital shall not commence any business or exercise any borrowing powers unless— ( a ) a declaration is filed by a director in such form and verified in such with the Registrar that every subscriber to the memorandum has paid the value of the shares agreed to be taken by him and the paid-up share capital of the company is not less than five lakh rupees in case of a public company and not less than one lakh rupees in case of a private company on the date of making of this declaration; and ( b ) the company has filed with the Registrar a verification of its registered office as provided in sub-section (2) of section 12. 21 (2) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company shall be liable to a penalty which may extend to five thousand rupees and every officer who is in default shall be punishable with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees for every day during which the default continues. (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause ( a ) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII. (3) Where no declaration has been filed with the Registrar under clause ( a ) of sub-section (1) within a period of one hundred and eighty days of the date of incorporation of the company and the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may, without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (2), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII.

Section 11 is Omitted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2015 (21 of 2015), notified on 26th May, 2015, with effect from 29th May 2015 vide notification S.O. 1440(E). To view the notification, Click Here

chunks.summary: A company with a share capital must file a declaration verifying that all subscribers have paid their shares and meet certain financial requirements before commencing business or borrowing powers. Non-compliance can result in fines for both the company and its officers, and failure to file within a specified period may lead to the removal of the company's name from the register under specific conditions.

chunks.title: Registered office of company
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: The entity is required to have a registered office with specific conditions for International Financial Services Centers (IFSC) and their licensed operating zones. This includes specifying the zone location and operational license requirements. The company must provide proof of its registered office within a stipulated period, ensuring compliance with legal documentation.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) A shall, on and from the fifteenth day of its incorporation and at all times thereafter, have a registered office capable of receiving and acknowledging all communications and notices as may be addressed to it. a Specified IFSC shall have its registered office at the International Financial Services Centre located in the approved multi services Special Economic Zone set-up under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006, where it is licensed to operate, at all times. a Specified IFSC private company shall have its registered office at the International Financial Services Centre located in the approved multi services Special Economic Zone set-up under the Special Economic Zones Act, 2005 read with the Special Economic Zones Rules, 2006, where it is licensed to operate, at all times.”. (2) The company shall furnish to the verification of its registered office within a period of of its incorporation in such (3) Every company shall—
chunks.summary: The text outlines specific requirements for a company's registered office address. The first part specifies that any company incorporated on or after the fifteenth day must have a registered office capable of receiving and acknowledging communications as addressed to it. For companies operating under Special Economic Zones, the registered office is mandated in an approved multi-services Special Economic Zone designated by the Special Economic Zones Act 2005, specifically with the Rules from 2006. Additionally, if the company is a private limited IFSC, its registered office must also be located within this zone and licensed to operate.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) paint or affix its name, and the address of its registered office, and keep the same painted or affixed, on the outside of every office or place in which its business is carried on, in a conspicuous position, in legible letters, and if the characters employed therefor are not those of the language or of one of the languages in general use in that locality, also in the characters of that language or of one of those languages;
chunks.summary: The legal text requires all business premises to display their name and registered office address in a prominent place on the exterior. The use of specific characters for these identifiers is mandatory unless they are not commonly used locally.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) have its name engraved in legible characters on its seal ;
chunks.summary: The legal text specifies that a company must have its name engraved in legible characters on its seal. This requirement pertains to the establishment and official documentation of the business.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) get its name, address of its registered office and the Corporate Identity Number along with telephone number, fax number, if any, e-mail and website addresses, if any, printed in all its business letters, billheads, letter papers and in all its notices and other official publications; and
chunks.summary: The company must provide accurate information about its name, registered office address, corporate identity number, contact details, and official publications in all business letters, billheads, letter papers, notices, and other documents. This ensures clarity for potential investors and regulators.

This requirement is an extension of clause requirements to ensure all relevant documents are updated accordingly.

chunks.summary: This legal text outlines key provisions and requirements related to companies incorporated in India. It includes detailed instructions for registered offices, changes in registered office locations, default officer liability, and specific rules concerning private and public companies within the International Financial Services Centre (IFSC). The document is part of updates and amendments made by various acts and notifications since 2015 and 2018, particularly focusing on company incorporation procedures.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary:
The summary involves key provisions, requirements, and legal implications regarding directors' responsibilities and accountability in a company. The text outlines specific roles for directorship that include whole-time directors, key managerial personnel with consent, and those with authority to oversee financial activities, including account maintenance, filing, and distribution of records.

These roles ensure clear accountability and responsibility within the company, emphasizing that all actions must be taken under authorized or specified circumstances. The summary highlights the importance of compliance areas such as Company Incorporation and Constitutional Documents (MOA & AOA), which are fundamental for establishing a legal framework within the company.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 3
chunks.text:
(3) Every company shall—

( a ) paint or affix its name, and the address of its registered office, and keep the same painted or affixed, on the outside of every office or place in which its business is carried on, in a conspicuous position, in legible letters, and if the characters employed therefor are not those of the language or of one of the languages in general use in that locality, also in the characters of that language or of one of those languages;

( b ) have its name engraved in legible characters on its seal ;

( c ) get its name, address of its registered office and the Corporate Identity Number along with telephone number, fax number, if any, e-mail and website addresses, if any, printed in all its business letters, billheads, letter papers and in all its notices and other official publications; and

( d ) have its name printed on hundies , promissory notes, bills of exchange and such other

Provided that where a company has changed its name or names during the last two years, it shall paint or affix or print, as the case may be, along with its name, the former name or names so changed during the last two years as required under clauses ( a ) and ( c ):

Provided further that the words ” ” shall be mentioned in brackets below the name of such company, wherever its name is printed, affixed or engraved.
chunks.summary: Companies are required to prominently display their name and registered office address on all business premises and documents. They must engrave or print their names in legible characters, along with essential information like contact details and an identity number. Companies can also update the old name they used for two years if necessary.

chunks.text:
(4) Notice of every change of the situation of the registered office, verified after the date of incorporation of the company, shall be given to the Registrar within fifteen days of the change, who shall record the same.

Changes require an official notice and are subject to approval by a special resolution unless specifically authorized. The summary also clarifies that changes cannot occur without such authority.

chunks.summary: This provision pertains to the designation of a registered office for an existing company that is situated outside the local limits of any city, town, or village where such office is currently located. The act also allows this designation later through a special resolution passed by the company itself.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 4 Clause b
chunks.text:
(b) in the case of any other company, outside the local limits of any city, town or village where such office is first situated or where it may be situated later by virtue of a special resolution passed by the company:

Provided that no company shall change the place of its registered office from the jurisdiction of one Registrar to the jurisdiction of another Registrar within the same State unless such change is confirmed by the Regional Director on an application made in this behalf by the company in the (6) The confirmation referred to in sub-section (5) shall be communicated within a period of thirty days from the date of receipt of application by the Regional Director to the company and the company shall file the confirmation with the Registrar within a period of sixty days of the date of confirmation who shall register the same and certify the registration within a period of thirty days from the date of filing of such confirmation. (7) The certificate referred to in sub-section (6) shall be conclusive evidence that all the requirements of this Act with respect to change of registered office in pursuance of sub-section (5) have been complied with and the change shall take effect from the date of the certificate. (8) If any default is made in complying with the requirements of this section, the company and every shall be liable to a penalty of one thousand rupees for every day during which the default continues but not exceeding one lakh rupees. If the Registrar has reasonable cause to believe that the company is not carrying on any business or operations, he may cause a physical verification of the registered office of the company in such manner as may be prescribed and if any default is found to be made in complying with the requirements of sub-section (1), he may without prejudice to the provisions of sub-section (8), initiate action for the removal of the name of the company from the register of companies under Chapter XVIII. 2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law Substituted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017 dated 03.01.2018, effective from 27.07.2018. chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 4 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The legal text outlines key provisions for directors' responsibilities in a company. It specifies that whole-time directors, or where there is no key managerial personnel, specified directors who consent to such designation by the Board, all directors collectively, or any person charged with responsibility under the immediate authority of the Board, must be aware and comply with certain duties.

chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer Inserted vide the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 dated 31.07.2019 w.e.f., 02.11.2018. chunks.summary: The Act addresses various aspects of a company's operations and management. It requires directors to act in accordance with advice given by their colleagues or through professional channels unless they object. It also specifies that share transfers must be handled by designated entities such as agents, registrars, and bankers. Additionally, it outlines the amendment procedures for changes within the Act.

chunks.summary: The Legal Text primarily focuses on amendments to the Companies Act, specifically addressing the registration and incorporation requirements for financial institutions (IFSC) private and public companies. It specifies that such companies must adhere to certain criteria regarding their registered offices within the International Financial Services Centre (IFSC). The document includes revised rules and notifications related to incorporation, including changes in terms of registration procedures, effect periods, and provisions on members and shareholders.

chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary: The summary of the legal text is provided below:

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.summary: The legal text specifies four types of directors who are considered key managerial personnel. A whole-time director is specified by the Board if none exist. Directors without specific designation must be those who consent in writing to such specification or all directors. Any person charged with responsibility for maintaining, filing, or distributing accounts or records can authorize actions that might result in a default. This includes individuals under direct authority of the Board or key managerial personnel.

chunks.title: Registered office of company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.summary: This amendment to the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 specifies that a person's advice or directions given on how the Board of Directors is accustomed to act, regardless of whether it involves professional input, are legally binding. Additionally, directors who participate in proceedings without objecting when aware of a violation, or those involved in share transfers with consent or connivance, may be held accountable. The amendment also outlines specific responsibilities for share transfer agents and includes provisions related to the conversion and commencement of business operations.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: This section outlines procedures for amending a company's name and memorandum. It specifies that amendments to the company's name must be approved by resolution followed by compliance with specific requirements as detailed in sections 4 and 5. The new name entry process ensures complete effectiveness of the change on issuance of a new certificate of incorporation, which is optional only if the sole alteration involves removing or adding the word 'Private'. Additionally, it clarifies that changes made under section 2 do not affect the registered office unless specified in this clause.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Save as provided in section 61, a may, by a special resolution and after complying with the procedure specified in this section, the provisions of its . (2) Any change in the name of a company shall be subject to the provisions of sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 4 and shall not have effect except with the approval of the Provided that no such approval shall be necessary where the only change in the name of the company is the deletion therefrom, or addition thereto, of the word “Private”, consequent on the conversion of any one class of companies to another class in accordance with the provisions of this Act. (3) When any change in the name of a company is made under sub-section (2), the shall enter the new name in the in place of the old name and issue a fresh certificate of incorporation with the new name and the change in the name shall be complete and effective only on the issue of such a certificate. (4) The alteration of the memorandum relating to the place of the registered office from one State to another shall not have any effect unless it is approved by the on an application in such as (5) The shall dispose of the application under sub-section (4) within a period of sixty days and before passing its order may satisfy itself that the alteration has the consent of the creditors, -holders and other persons concerned with the company or that the sufficient provision has been made by the company either for the due discharge of all its debts and obligations or that adequate security has been provided for such discharge. (6) Save as provided in section 64, a company shall, in relation to any alteration of its memorandum, file with the Registrar—
chunks.summary: A special resolution can amend a company's provisions. Changing a company’s name requires approval except for deletions or additions involving private companies as per conversion rules. When changing a company's name, the new one must be entered in the register and accompanied by a certificate of incorporation. Altering the registered office without creditor consent is not effective unless approved, and compliance with creditors is required within 60 days.

This resolution must be adhered to comply with corporate governance regulations, ensuring transparency in decision-making processes.

(7) Where an alteration of the memorandum results in the transfer of the registered office of a company from one State to another, a certified copy of the order of the Central Government approving the alteration shall be filed by the company with the Registrar of each of the States within such time and in who shall register the same, and the Registrar of the State where the registered office is being shifted to, shall issue a fresh certificate of incorporation indicating the alteration. chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions related to changes in a company's memorandum (MOA) and articles of association (AOA). It mentions that an alteration in the name requires Central Government approval. If a change in the registered office leads to a shift, it must be filed with the Registrar of the new State. A company raising money through prospectus cannot alter its objects without special resolution unless there is unutilized capital from the prospectus period. The text also notes that changes need to comply with certain procedural requirements.

chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) of a company must be registered with the Companies Office for compliance. Only the subscribers to these documents who have signed them can become members of the company. All other individuals, even those holding shares or beneficial ownership records in a depository, are also considered members once their names appear on the register of members.

chunks.summary: The text outlines that any alterations made under section 10(6) require registration in accordance with Section 2(10). It also clarifies that memorandums and alterations are not altered to give rights to participate in divisible profits unless it pertains specifically. The document discusses the revision of Form INC-24, including the changes detailed in MCA Notifications dated 19.01.2023. It specifies the duties of a Registrar and includes rules for registering companies, amendments, and notifications related to these actions.

chunks.summary: The Companies (Incorporation) Amendment Rules, 2023 have been modified to enhance filing and registration capabilities for companies. The revision includes changes to Form INC-28, enabling filings under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code and second amendment rules, as well as modifications to Prospectus and Promoter definitions in Rule 32 of the Companies (Incorporation) Rules, 2014. This update aims to streamline compliance processes for companies incorporated through these regulations.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 7 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository
chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) or articles of association (AOA) is a document that outlines the fundamental principles and rules governing a company. Upon registration, subscribers to the MOA are considered members, while written agreements by other parties become members if their names are listed in the register. Beneficial ownership records also affect member status through depositories. This establishes clear legal frameworks for membership, shares, and shareholder rights within the company.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 8
chunks.summary: A company that has raised funds from public and still retains unused funds must not change its purposes without a special resolution. The resolution must be published in newspapers (English and vernacular) at the company’s registered office location and should also be posted on the company’s website, along with justification for the change.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) The Registrar shall register any alteration of the memorandum with respect to the objects of the company and certify the registration within a period of thirty days from the date of filing of the special resolution in accordance with clause ( a ) of sub-section (6) of this section.
chunks.summary: The Registrar is required to register any alteration of the memorandum with respect to the objects of the company and must certify this within thirty days from filing a special resolution according to sub-section (6) clause (a). This ensures timely registration of such changes.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 10

chunks.summary: This section prohibits any alteration made under the previous chapter without registration. It emphasizes the need for adherence to these provisions and their subsequent application.

chunks.summary: The document primarily deals with the legal framework governing companies under an updated version of Indian Company Act, 2013. It includes changes to sections related to amendments and alterations in memorandums, powers delegated to various officials, updates to forms for incorporation, and modifications to the company's constitutional documents. Key provisions emphasize the need for adherence to existing regulations and the importance of maintaining accurate records. The compliance area is closely tied to 'Company Incorporation' due to the focus on changes that affect how companies are formed.

chunks.summary:
The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) for a company must be registered with the relevant government authority. The registration of these documents includes any other person who agrees in writing to become a member and whose name is entered in the register of members. Additionally, every beneficial owner holding shares must also have their name listed as such in the records of a depository.

These provisions are designed to ensure transparency and accountability within the company structure.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum - Subsection 11 Clause i
chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) serve as foundational documents for a company. A person who agrees to become a member of the company through written agreement and whose name is registered becomes a member, and their consent is deemed valid upon registration. This document outlines key provisions such as the extent and commencement of business operations, share capital management, and voting rights. The memorandum also covers issues like beneficial ownership, the register of members, and acceptance of deposits.

chunks.title: Alteration of articles
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: The Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019 allows a company to convert from private to public status through specific legal procedures and approvals. Any conversion must comply with specified requirements; alterations altering a private company into a public one without Government approval are not valid. Pending applications prior to the Act’s commencement date will be handled by the Tribunal.
keywords: conversion from private to public status

chunks.text: (a) a into a ; or
chunks.summary: This document outlines the requirements for a company's formation and operation, including aspects such as incorporation, registration, share capital, issuance of securities, prospectus, allotment and transfer of shares, buy-backs, deposits, charges, membership rights, and compliance with member requirements. The summary emphasizes the importance of adhering to legal standards to ensure smooth business operations.

chunks.title: Alteration of articles - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) a public company into a private company: Provided that where a company being a private company alters its articles in such a manner that they no longer include the restrictions and limitations which are required to be included in the articles of a private company under this Act, the company shall, as from the date of such alteration, cease to be a private company: any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the Central Government on an application made in such form and manner as may be prescribed: any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2019, shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement. any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not be valid unless it is approved by an order of the on an application made in such form and manner : Provided also that any application pending before the Tribunal, as on the date of commencement of the Companies (Amendment) Ordinance, 2018 , shall be disposed of by the Tribunal in accordance with the provisions applicable to it before such commencement. Provided further that any alteration having the effect of conversion of a public company into a private company shall not take effect except with the approval of the which shall make such order as it may deem fit. (2) Every alteration of the articles under this section and a copy of the order of the Tribunal approving the alteration as per sub-section (1) , together with a printed copy of the altered articles, within a period of fifteen days in who shall register the same. (3) Any alteration of the articles registered under sub-section (2) shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, be valid as if it were originally in the articles. 2(56) Memorandum means the memorandum of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law alter includes the making of additions, omissions and substitutions. Articles means the articles of association of a company as originally framed or as altered from time to time or applied in pursuance of any previous company law or of this Act 2(68) Private company means a company having a minimum paid-up share capital as may be prescribed, and which by its articles, —
chunks.summary: Section 497 of the Companies Act, 2019 provides guidelines for private company conversions from public to private status. A company that becomes a private entity must change its articles and obtain approval from the Central Government. Pending applications before tribunals will be processed according to existing laws until June 30, 2019, or December 31, 2018, depending on which was in effect at the time of amendment.

The key provisions require companies to have a minimum paid-up share capital and include amendments that apply to private subsidiaries as public companies.

chunks.summary: The section provides a mechanism for altering certain articles or memorandums and registering these alterations. The alteration must be made within fifteen days after it is approved by a tribunal, followed by filing with a specific authority. Alterations are valid as if they were originally in the articles unless otherwise specified under this Act or prior company laws.

The key points include alterations to the memorandum and articles of association (MOA/AAO) being valid as originally framed or altered according to previous laws, the definition of 'company' as including those under current and past laws, and provisions related to the effectiveness of such amendments.

chunks.text: (i) restricts the right to transfer its shares; ( ii ) except in case of One Person Company, limits the number of its members to two hundred: Provided that where two or more persons hold one or more shares in a company jointly, they shall, for the purposes of this clause, be treated as a single member: Provided further that— ( A ) persons who are in the employment of the company; and ( B ) persons who, having been formerly in the employment of the company, were members of the company while in that employment and have continued to be members after the employment ceased, shall not be included in the number of members; and ( iii ) prohibits any invitation to the public to subscribe for any securities of the company
chunks.summary: This legal text restricts the transferability of shares, limits the number of members to two hundred (with joint holders counted as one), and prohibits inviting the public to subscribe for securities. It also requires employees and former employees who were previously employed by the company but remain members after employment termination not to be included in the membership count.

It also prohibits public subscriptions for securities, impacting employment-related members and prohibiting invitations to the public to subscribe. The legal implications are significant for company operations, especially in relation to employment-based shareholders.

chunks.summary: This section stipulates that a company must have minimum paid-up share capital to qualify as a public company. A subsidiary of a non-private company will be treated as a public company for this purpose. This is important for determining whether a company falls under the scope of public company regulations.

chunks.summary: The document provides detailed provisions for public and private companies in India, including requirements for share capital, issuance of securities, prospectus, registration of charges, and more. The amendments are effective from November 2, 2018, and require compliance with certain rules, regulations, and notifications.

chunks.title: Alteration of memorandum or articles to be noted in every copy
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of a company must be updated whenever they are altered. Companies that fail to comply with this requirement may face penalties of one thousand rupees per copy of the revised document issued without the required changes. Officers, including directors and key personnel, can be held accountable for maintaining compliance under specific provisions in the Act.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: Regulation 45 of LODR (1) stipulates that upon the initial registration or subsequent change in name, a company must rectify its name if it is identical with or too closely resembling another registered company's name. The company needs to do this within three months after receiving a direction from an authority and obtain an ordinary resolution for the purpose. For trade marks, companies are required to notify the Central Government within three years of incorporation or changing their name.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 1
chunks.summary: The legislation addresses situations where a company name registration is based on a prior registered name. In such cases, if it's identical or too similar to another company’s existing name, it requires the company to change its name within specified periods after adopting resolutions. The Central Government can also direct companies to rename themselves in instances of trade marks infringement.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) Where a company changes its name or obtains a new name under sub-section (1), it shall within a period of fifteen days from the date of such change, give notice of the change to the along with the order of the Central Government, who shall carry out necessary changes in the certificate of incorporation and the .

If a company is in default in complying with any direction given under sub-section (1), the Central Government shall allot a new name to the company in such manner as may be prescribed and the Registrar shall enter the new name in the register of companies in place of the old name and issue a fresh certificate of incorporation with the new name, which the company shall use thereafter:

Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall prevent a company from subsequently changing its name in accordance with the provisions of section 13.
chunks.summary: A company changing its name must notify the Central Government within fifteen days and undergo necessary changes. If a default occurs in complying with direction under section 13(1), a new name is allotted by the Central Government, and the old name is replaced with the new one. The company can then change its name again according to Section 13.

It also references General Circular 04/2017 to clarify certain points. Key points include penalties for default in complying with direction, potential fines ranging from one thousand to one lakh rupees, and the delegation of powers related to notification S.O. 1352(E) and S.O. 4090(E). The summary covers legal implications without delving into detailed compliance areas.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) Acts relating to companies in force before the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( ii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1866 (10 of 1866); ( iii ) the Indian Companies Act, 1882 (6 of 1882); ( iv ) the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913);
chunks.summary: The text discusses four sets of Indian Company Acts ranging from before to after 1866. It includes provisions on pre-1866 acts, 1866 act, 1882 act, and 1913 act. The summary covers the initial incorporation requirements, constitutional documents (MOA & AOA), registered office and name, conversion of companies, commencement of business, share capital, issue of securities, prospectus and capital raising, allotment and transfer of securities, buy-back of securities, acceptance of deposits, charges registration, members' rights, beneficial ownership, register of members, voting rights. The key provisions cover the company's inception through its operations.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) the Registration of Transferred Companies Ordinance, 1942 (Ord. 54 of 1942); ( vi ) the Companies Act, 1956 (1 of 1956); and ( vii ) any law corresponding to any of the aforesaid Acts or the Ordinances and in force— ( A ) in the merged territories or in a Part B State (other than the State of Jammu and Kashmir), or any part thereof, before the extension thereto of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (7 of 1913); or ( B ) in the State of Jammu and Kashmir, or any part thereof, before the commencement of the Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act, 1956 (62 of 1956), in so far as banking, insurance and financial corporations are concerned, and before the commencement of the Central Laws (Extension to Jammu and Kashmir) Act, 1968 (25 of 1968), in so far as other corporations are concerned; ( viii ) the Portuguese Commercial Code, in so far as it relates to sociedades anonimas ; and ( ix ) the Registration of Companies (Sikkim) Act, 1961 (Sikkim Act 8 of 1961)(Not notified)
chunks.summary:
The document outlines various legal instruments that may affect companies registered under specific jurisdictions. It references laws such as the Companies Act 1956 and Ordinances from 1942, which apply to certain territories or states before their incorporation of relevant legislation like the Indian Companies Act 1913 and Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act 1956 for banking, insurance, and financial corporations. The Portuguese Commercial Code is also referenced, particularly in relation to sociedades anónimas.

It specifies that these laws can override existing MOAs or AOA documents if applicable, affecting the company's registered office, name, conversion of companies, commencement of business, share capital, securities issue, prospectus and registration of charges. The document highlights the need for compliance with all relevant legal provisions to ensure proper incorporation and operation of companies.

Keywords: Companies Act 1956, Ordinances from 1942, Portuguese Commercial Code, Sikkim Act 8 of 1961, Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act 1956, Indian Companies Act 1913, Jammu and Kashmir (Extension of Laws) Act 1956, Central Laws (Extension to Jammu and Kashmir) Act 1968, Sociedades anónimas.

It discusses changes in company incorporation, registered office and name, conversion of companies, commencement of business, share capital, issue and registration of securities, allotment and transfer, buy-back of securities, acceptance of deposits, charges registration, and members' rights.

The amendments extend the Act's coverage to certain parts of merged territories, Part B States, and specific corporate regulations from other laws such as the Portuguese Commercial Code and Sikkim's Registration of Companies Act. The changes also address default liability officers and effect dates for notifications.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: Legal provision requiring compliance.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary: The text specifies that any person following advice given by the Board's directors, even if they did not object to or consent to a violation committed with their knowledge, is considered guilty. It also mentions the share transfer agents' responsibility for issues and transfers of shares.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause i
chunks.summary: This legal text defines and specifies roles for directors within a company. It outlines that any director should be whole-time, key managerial personnel, or follow specified Board instructions with consent, while also including individuals charged with responsibility for account maintenance, distribution, and filing who agree to such specifications. This setup aims to ensure accountability and compliance with corporate governance.

chunks.title: Rectification of name of company - Subsection 3 Clause v
chunks.summary: The text specifies various provisions concerning directors' responsibilities, including guidance on board behavior and compliance with company policies. Directors must act according to advice or instructions without objecting to proceedings, which includes share transfers if they did not object beforehand.

It also specifies that such conversions do not affect pre-existing debts, liabilities, obligations, or contracts of the converted company.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: Under this section, shareholders are prohibited from holding or transferring shares in their parent company. This restriction applies to companies not involving cases where a subsidiary holds shares on behalf of a deceased parent or as a trustee. The right to vote is limited for the shareholder's right during the period of legal representation or trust. No provision allows the transfer or allotment of shares if it would violate this section.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) No company shall, either by itself or through its nominees, hold any in its holding company and no shall allot or transfer its shares to any of its and any such allotment or transfer of shares of a company to its subsidiary company shall be void: Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply to a case— ( a ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as the legal representative of a deceased of the holding company; or ( b ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as a trustee; or ( c ) where the subsidiary company is a shareholder even before it became a subsidiary company of the holding company: Provided further that the subsidiary company referred to in the preceding proviso shall have a right to vote at a meeting of the holding company only in respect of the shares held by it as a legal representative or as a trustee, as referred to in clause ( a ) or clause ( b ) of the said proviso. (2) The reference in this section to the shares of a holding company which is a or an , not having a share capital, shall be construed as a reference to the interest of its members, whatever be the form of interest. 2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock 2(46) Holding Company , in relation to one or more other companies, means a company of which such companies are subsidiary companies. Explanation.- For the purposes of this clause, the expression “company” includes any body corporate; 2(87) Subsidiary Company or Subsidiary , in relation to any other company (that is to say the holding company), means a company in which the holding company— (i) controls the composition of the Board of Directors; or (ii) exercises or controls more than one-half of the total voting power either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies: Provided that such class or classes of holding companies as may be prescribed shall not have layers of subsidiaries beyond such numbers  as may be prescribed. Explanation.—For the purposes of this clause,— (a) a company shall be deemed to be a subsidiary company of the holding company even if the control referred to in sub-clause (i) or sub-clause (ii) is of another subsidiary company of the holding company; (b) the composition of a company’s Board of Directors shall be deemed to be controlled by another company if that other company by exercise of some power exercisable by it at its discretion can appoint or remove all or a majority of the directors; (c) the expression “company” includes any body corporate; (d) “layer” in relation to a holding company means its subsidiary or subsidiaries. 2(55) Member , in relation to a company, means— ( i ) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository 2(21) Company limited by guarantee means a company having the liability of its members limited by the memorandum to such amount as the members may respectively undertake to contribute to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound up 2(92) Unlimited Company means a company not having any limit on the liability of its members
chunks.summary: This legal document establishes several key provisions regarding shareholdings and subsidiaries within a holding company structure. It restricts certain transfers of shares to only specific situations such as legal representatives or trustees holding on behalf of deceased shareholders. Additionally, it clarifies that members' rights extend beyond the mere subscription agreement and incorporate elements like depositories for managing registered securities. This document is part of the regulation concerning corporate governance and shareholdings within a multi-layered structure.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) No company shall, either by itself or through its nominees, hold any in its holding company and no shall allot or transfer its shares to any of its and any such allotment or transfer of shares of a company to its subsidiary company shall be void:

Provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply to a case—

( a ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as the legal representative of a deceased of the holding company; or

( b ) where the subsidiary company holds such shares as a trustee; or

( c ) where the subsidiary company is a shareholder even before it became a subsidiary company of the holding company:

Provided further that the subsidiary company referred to in the preceding proviso shall have a right to vote at a meeting of the holding company only in respect of the shares held by it as a legal representative or as a trustee, as referred to in clause ( a ) or clause ( b ) of the said proviso.
chunks.summary: The summary highlights that no holding company is allowed to directly hold shares within its own subsidiary. Exceptions are provided for cases where a deceased legal representative or trustee holds such shares prior to the subsidiary's incorporation, allowing them to participate in shareholder meetings only on behalf of those they represent. This regulation underscores an important distinction between direct ownership and nominee holdings.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause 1
chunks.summary: This section clarifies that a holding company's shares are considered as its members' interests. It also defines 'subsidiary' companies and specifies what constitutes a 'company'. This clarification is relevant to understanding the scope of legal responsibilities within the context of multiple companies.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) controls the composition of the Board of Directors; or (ii) exercises or controls more than one-half of the total voting power either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies: Provided that such class or classes of holding companies as may be prescribed shall not have layers of subsidiaries beyond such numbers  as may be prescribed. Explanation.—For the purposes of this clause,—
chunks.summary: This clause outlines the conditions under which a holding company may be deemed to control or exercise substantial voting power over other companies. It specifies that such holding companies are subject to certain restrictions and limitations on their ability to influence corporate governance, including requiring them to either be part of a limited number of layers of subsidiaries or not have any specific prescribed classes of themselves as subsidiary holdings.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) a company shall be deemed to be a subsidiary company of the holding company even if the control referred to in sub-clause
chunks.summary: This text outlines that a company is considered to be a subsidiary of its holding company even if control is not explicitly stated in the memorandum and articles of association (MOA & AOA). This definition has legal implications for governance, registration, share capital management, and compliance with regulations related to corporate structure.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) or sub-clause (ii) is of another subsidiary company of the holding company;
chunks.summary: The text discusses a subsidiary company's incorporation, conversion to another holding company's subsidiary, and related legal implications. The summary covers key points such as the source of the subsidiary (another subsidiary of the holding company) and the impact on the original parent company.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the composition of a company’s Board of Directors shall be deemed to be controlled by another company if that other company by exercise of some power exercisable by it at its discretion can appoint or remove all or a majority of the directors;
chunks.summary: In a company where another entity holds control over certain aspects that influence the composition of its Board of Directors, this is considered as being controlled by that other entity. The exercise of discretion allows for the appointment or removal of directors to be done by them at their own discretion.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) the expression “company” includes any body corporate;
chunks.summary: The text clarifies that 'company' includes any body corporate. This definition is significant for interpreting statutes and regulations dealing with companies.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause d
chunks.text: (d) “layer” in relation to a holding company means its subsidiary or subsidiaries.
chunks.summary: This definition pertains to a holding company’s subsidiaries. It clarifies that the term 'layer' relates specifically to the subsidiary or subsidiaries controlled by the holding company.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text:
(i) controls the composition of the Board of Directors; or

(ii) exercises or controls more than one-half of the total voting power either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies:

Provided that such class or classes of holding companies as may be prescribed shall not have layers of subsidiaries beyond such numbers  as may be prescribed.

Explanation.—For the purposes of this clause,—
chunks.summary:
The provided text outlines specific provisions regarding controlling class of holding companies. It states that a holding company must either have control over the Board of Directors or exercise more than half of the total voting power to be considered as having layers of subsidiaries beyond prescribed limits. Additionally, it specifies an exemption for certain classes of holding companies.

The summary emphasizes the importance of compliance and interpretation in legal matters related to holding company classification and subsidiary structure.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) a company shall be deemed to be a subsidiary company of the holding company even if the control referred to in sub-clause
chunks.summary: The company is considered a subsidiary of the holding company if it can be demonstrated that one party holds a significant share in the ownership or control structure of another entity.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) or sub-clause (ii) is of another subsidiary company of the holding company;
chunks.summary: Sub-clause (i) or sub-clause (ii) refers to another subsidiary company within a holding company. This indicates that the specific provisions being referred to are part of an internal corporate structure rather than external regulations.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the composition of a company’s Board of Directors shall be deemed to be controlled by another company if that other company by exercise of some power exercisable by it at its discretion can appoint or remove all or a majority of the directors;
chunks.summary: A company's Board of Directors is deemed controlled by another company when that other company can appoint or remove all or a majority of directors through exercising power at its discretion.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) the expression “company” includes any body corporate;
chunks.summary: The expression 'company' includes any body corporate. This means that a company can be defined as an entity with legal personality such as a corporation or partnership.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause d
chunks.text:
(d) “layer” in relation to a holding company means its subsidiary or subsidiaries.

2(55) Member , in relation to a company, means—

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository
chunks.summary: The memorandum and articles of association (MOA and AOA) govern the rights, duties, and obligations of members, beneficial owners, shareholders, and other relevant parties in a company. The agreement to join as a member is considered effective upon registration, with specific entries made in the register of members and any depository records reflecting ownership changes. This summary covers key provisions, requirements, and legal implications.

chunks.title: Subsidiary company not to hold shares in its holding company - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) provide essential legal documents for a company. The MOA outlines the fundamental principles and rules governing the formation and operation of the company, while the AOA details the additional agreements that members may enter into.

(2) Save as provided in this Act or the rules made there under for filing of documents with the in electronic mode, on Registrar or any by sending it to him by post or by registered post or by speed post or by courier or by delivering at his office or address, or by such electronic or other mode Provided that a member may request for delivery of any document through a particular mode, for which he shall pay such fees as may be determined by the company in its annual general meeting. chunks.title: Authentication of documents, proceedings and contracts
chunks.summary: The legal text outlines provisions for signing documents requiring company authentication or being signed by authorized officers. It specifies that summons, notices, requisitions, orders, declarations, forms, and registers can be maintained on paper or electronically. Key managerial personnel include CEO/MD/manager, company secretary, whole-time directors, Chief Financial Officer, and others appointed by the Board as key managerial personnel. The text also updates certain notifications regarding definitions and regulations for specific companies like IFSC Private and Public.

chunks.title: Execution of bills of exchange, etc.
chunks.text:
(1) A bill of exchange, hundi or promissory note shall be deemed to have been made, accepted, drawn or endorsed on behalf of a if made, accepted, drawn, or endorsed in the name of, or on behalf of or on account of, the company by any person acting under its authority, express or implied. (2) A company may, by writing under its common seal , authorise any person, either generally or in respect of any specified matters, as its attorney to execute other deeds on its behalf in any place either in or outside India. (3) A deed signed by such an attorney on behalf of the company and under his seal shall bind the company 2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law inserted by the Companies (Amendment) Act, 2015 (21 of 2015), notified on 26th May, 2015, with effect from 29th May 2015 vide notification S.O. 1440(E). chunks.title: Public offer and private placement
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: Regulation 32 of LODR (1) authorizes issuers to issue securities through public offerings and private placements in accordance with specified conditions. It also provides a rights issue or bonus issue for certain companies, including those seeking listing on foreign exchanges as per the India Act, 1992, and its rules. The regulation emphasizes compliance under this Act, potentially affecting multiple areas such as MOA/AAO alteration, share capital issues, and registration of securities.

chunks.title: Public offer and private placement - Subsection 1
chunks.text:
(1) A may issue —

( a ) to public through (herein referred to as “public offer”) by complying with the provisions of this Part; or

( b ) through private placement by complying with the provisions of Part II of this Chapter; or (Effective from 01-04-2014)

( c ) through a rights issue or a bonus issue in accordance with the provisions of this Act and in case of a or a company which intends to get its securities listed also with the provisions of the of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) and the rules and regulations made thereunder.
chunks.summary: Public and private issuances are permitted under this chapter. Public issuance can be through a public offer or by complying with Part II's provisions. Private placements must adhere to Chapter II's rules. Additionally, rights issues and bonus issues need adherence to the Act and relevant laws like India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992), as well as regulations made thereunder.

chunks.summary: The text specifies that a subsidiary company of a non-private company is deemed to be public for the purposes of this Act. It also clarifies that certain provisions within the Act apply even if the subsidiary continues as a private company in its articles, under specific conditions.

chunks.title: Public offer and private placement - Subsection 2 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) restricts the right to transfer its shares; ( ii ) except in case of One Person Company, limits the number of its members to two hundred: Provided that where two or more persons hold one or more shares in a company jointly, they shall, for the purposes of this clause, be treated as a single member: Provided further that— ( A ) persons who are in the employment of the company; and ( B ) persons who, having been formerly in the employment of the company, were members of the company while in that employment and have continued to be members after the employment ceased, shall not be included in the number of members; and ( iii ) prohibits any invitation to the public to subscribe for any securities of the company

It also prohibits public invitations for securities subscriptions and invites employees and those who were formerly part of the company but have continued as members, not including them in the membership count.
