chunks.title: Power of Securities and Exchange Board to regulate issue and transfer of securities, etc.
chunks.text:
Regulation 28 of LODR (1) The provisions contained in this Chapter, Chapter IV and in section 127 shall,— ( a ) in so far as they relate to — ( i ) issue and transfer of ; and ( ii ) non-payment of dividend, by listed companies or those companies which intend to get their securities listed on any in India, except as provided under this Act, be administered by the by making regulations in this behalf; ( b ) in any other case, be administered by the Central Government. Explanation .—For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that all powers relating to all other matters relating to , return of allotment, redemption of preference and any other matter specifically provided in this Act, shall be exercised by the Central Government, or the , as the case may be. (2) The Securities and Exchange Board shall, in respect of matters specified in sub-section (1) and the matters delegated to it under proviso to sub-section (1) of section 458, exercise the powers conferred upon it under sub-sections (1), (2A), (3) and (4) of section 11, sections 11A, 11B and 11D of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992). 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(73) Recognised stock exchange means a recognised stock exchange as defined in clause( f ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate 2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock Until Tribunal (NCLT) is setup, Company Law Board shall exercise power under this section vide notification S.O. 1459(E). To view the notification, Click Here 2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act

Regulation 28 of LODR

(1) The provisions contained in this Chapter, Chapter IV and in section 127 shall,—

( a ) in so far as they relate to —

( i ) issue and transfer of ; and

( ii ) non-payment of dividend,

by listed companies or those companies which intend to get their securities listed on any in India, except as provided under this Act, be administered by the by making regulations in this behalf;

( b ) in any other case, be administered by the Central Government.

Explanation .—For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that all powers relating to all other matters relating to , return of allotment, redemption of preference and any other matter specifically provided in this Act, shall be exercised by the Central Government, or the , as the case may be.

(2) The Securities and Exchange Board shall, in respect of matters specified in sub-section (1) and the matters delegated to it under proviso to sub-section (1) of section 458, exercise the powers conferred upon it under sub-sections (1), (2A), (3) and (4) of section 11, sections 11A, 11B and 11D of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992).

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(73) Recognised stock exchange means a recognised stock exchange as defined in clause( f ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992)

2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock

Until Tribunal (NCLT) is setup, Company Law Board shall exercise power under this section vide notification S.O. 1459(E). To view the notification, Click Here

2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act
chunks.summary: This regulation establishes specific administrative responsibilities for certain provisions related to listed companies and their securities. It also clarifies that powers relating to matters within this Act are exercised by either the Central Government or the Securities Exchange Board as specified.

chunks.title: Document containing offer of securities for sale to be deemed prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) Where a allots or agrees to allot any of the company with a view to all or any of those securities being offered for sale to the public, any by which the offer for sale to the public is made shall, for all purposes, be deemed to be a issued by the company; and all enactments and rules of law as to the contents of prospectus and as to liability in respect of mis-statements, in and omissions from, prospectus, or otherwise relating to prospectus, shall apply with the modifications specified in sub-sections (3) and (4) and shall have effect accordingly, as if the securities had been offered to the public for subscription and as if persons accepting the offer in respect of any securities were subscribers for those securities, but without prejudice to the liability, if any, of the persons by whom the offer is made in respect of mis-statements contained in the document or otherwise in respect thereof. (2) For the purposes of this Act, it shall, unless the contrary is proved, be evidence that an allotment of, or an agreement to allot, securities was made with a view to the securities being offered for sale to the public if it is shown— ( a ) that an offer of the securities or of any of them for sale to the public was made within six months after the allotment or agreement to allot; or ( b ) that at the date when the offer was made, the whole consideration to be received by the company in respect of the securities had not been received by it. (3) Section 26 as applied by this section shall have effect as if — ( i ) it required a prospectus to state in addition to the matters required by that section to be stated in a prospectus— ( a ) the net amount of the consideration received or to be received by the company in respect of the securities to which the offer relates; and ( b ) the time and place at which the contract where under the said securities have been or are to be allotted may be inspected; ( ii ) the persons making the offer were persons named in a prospectus as of a company.(Effective from 01-04-2014) (4) Where a person making an offer to which this section relates is a company or a firm, it shall be sufficient if the document referred to in sub-section (1) is signed on behalf of the company or firm by two directors of the company or by not less than one-half of the partners in the firm, as the case may be. 2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(36) Document includes summons, notice, requisition, order, declaration, form and register, whether issued, sent or kept in pursuance of this Act or under any other law for the time being in force or otherwise, maintained on paper or in electronic form 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate 2(34) Director means a director appointed to the Board of a company

(1) Where a allots or agrees to allot any of the company with a view to all or any of those securities being offered for sale to the public, any by which the offer for sale to the public is made shall, for all purposes, be deemed to be a issued by the company; and all enactments and rules of law as to the contents of prospectus and as to liability in respect of mis-statements, in and omissions from, prospectus, or otherwise relating to prospectus, shall apply with the modifications specified in sub-sections (3) and (4) and shall have effect accordingly, as if the securities had been offered to the public for subscription and as if persons accepting the offer in respect of any securities were subscribers for those securities, but without prejudice to the liability, if any, of the persons by whom the offer is made in respect of mis-statements contained in the document or otherwise in respect thereof.

(2) For the purposes of this Act, it shall, unless the contrary is proved, be evidence that an allotment of, or an agreement to allot, securities was made with a view to the securities being offered for sale to the public if it is shown—

( a ) that an offer of the securities or of any of them for sale to the public was made within six months after the allotment or agreement to allot; or

( b ) that at the date when the offer was made, the whole consideration to be received by the company in respect of the securities had not been received by it.

(3) Section 26 as applied by this section shall have effect as if —

( i ) it required a prospectus to state in addition to the matters required by that section to be stated in a prospectus—

( a ) the net amount of the consideration received or to be received by the company in respect of the securities to which the offer relates; and

( b ) the time and place at which the contract where under the said securities have been or are to be allotted may be inspected;

( ii ) the persons making the offer were persons named in a prospectus as of a company.(Effective from 01-04-2014)

(4) Where a person making an offer to which this section relates is a company or a firm, it shall be sufficient if the document referred to in sub-section (1) is signed on behalf of the company or firm by two directors of the company or by not less than one-half of the partners in the firm, as the case may be.

2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(36) Document includes summons, notice, requisition, order, declaration, form and register, whether issued, sent or kept in pursuance of this Act or under any other law for the time being in force or otherwise, maintained on paper or in electronic form

2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

2(34) Director means a director appointed to the Board of a company
chunks.summary: This legal text pertains to provisions concerning the issuance and allotment of securities by a company. It states that where a company allots or agrees to allot any of its securities with the intention of offering them for sale to the public, such allotments shall be deemed as issued by the company for the purpose of prospectuses and other legal considerations. The law specifies modifications in sections (3) and (4), which apply prospectus regulations and liabilities where an offer is made without prejudice to existing liability. This applies to companies or firms making offers within six months after the allotment.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: Issued documents by or on behalf of a public company must include detailed information about registered offices, board members, opening and closing dates of the issue, details about monies received, consent from directors and auditors, and provisions for issue acceptance. The document is dated and signed with specific requirements that affect the separate bank account for funds transferred and disclose details of previous issues.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Every issued by or on behalf of a either with reference to its formation or subsequently, or by or on behalf of any person who is or has been engaged or interested in the formation of a public company, shall be dated and signed and shall— state the
chunks.summary: This document specifies that any issued or created with reference to the formation of a public company must have a specific date and signature. It states that these documents should indicate the details of the entity's formation or subsequent changes, including the person(s) involved in its creation.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) names and addresses of the registered office of the company, Company Secretary , Chief Financial Officer , auditors, legal advisers, bankers, trustees, if any, underwriters and such other persons ( ii ) dates of the opening and closing of the issue, and declaration about the issue of allotment letters and refunds within the ( iii ) a statement by the Board of Director s a bout the separate bank account where all monies received out of the issue are to be transferred and disclosure of details of all monies including utilised and unutilised monies out of the previous issue in the ( iv ) details about
chunks.summary: The text provides key information about a company's financial and operational details. It includes the names and addresses of relevant officials, dates for issue opening and closing, statements regarding issues and refunds, separate bank accounts where funds are to be transferred, and details about previous issues' monies including utilised and unutilized amounts.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) consent of the directors , auditors, bankers to the issue, expert’s opinion, if any, and of such other persons, ( vi ) the authority for the issue and the details of the resolution passed therefor; ( vii ) procedure and time schedule for allotment and issue of securities (viii ) capital structure of the company in the prescribed manner; ( ix ) main objects of public offer, terms of the present issue and such other particulars
chunks.summary: The legal text includes provisions on directors' consent, auditors' approval, bankers' agreement, expert opinions (if any), authority for the issue, and details of resolutions passed. It specifies a procedure and schedule for allotment and issuance of securities, requires capital structure disclosure in prescribed manner, outlines main objectives, terms of the public offering, and other relevant particulars.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause x
chunks.text: (x) main objects and present business of the company and its location, schedule of implementation of the project; (xi)particulars relating to— ( A ) management perception of risk factors specific to the project; ( B ) gestation period of the project; ( C ) extent of progress made in the project; ( D ) deadlines for completion of the project; and ( E ) any litigation or legal action pending or taken by a Government Department or a statutory body during the last five years immediately preceding the year of the issue of prospectus against the promoter of the company; (xii)minimum subscription, amount payable by way of premium, issue of shares otherwise than on cash; (xiii)d etails of directors including their appointments and , and such particulars of the nature and extent of their interests in the company and (xiv)disclosures in such manner about sources of promoter’s contribution; set out the following reports for the purposes of the financial information, namely:—
chunks.summary: The summary provides detailed information about a company's main business activities and project schedule. It includes management perceptions of potential risks, details on the gestation period of projects, progress, deadlines for completion, pending legal actions by government bodies or statutory authorities in the last five years, minimum subscription requirements, issuance terms including premium payment methods, directorial appointments, their interests, and disclosures about promoter's contributions. The report must be made public through a prospectus, and all reports are to cover financial information required under securities regulations.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) reports by the auditors of the company with respect to its profits and losses and assets and liabilities and such other matters ( ii ) reports relating to profits and losses for each of the five immediately preceding the financial year of the issue of prospectus including such reports of its and in such manner Provided that in case of a company with respect to which a period of five years has not elapsed from the date of incorporation, the prospectus shall set out in such manner , the reports relating to profits and losses for each of the financial years immediately preceding the financial year of the issue of prospectus including such reports of its subsidiaries; ( iii ) reports made in the by the auditors upon the profits and losses of the business of the company for each of the five financial years immediately preceding issue and assets and liabilities of its business on the last date to which the accounts of the business were made up, being a date not more than one hundred and eighty days before the issue of the prospectus: Provided that in case of a company with respect to which a period of five years has not elapsed from the date of incorporation, the prospectus shall set out in the prescribed manner, the reports made by the auditors upon the profits and losses of the business of the company for all financial years from the date of its incorporation, and assets and liabilities of its business on the last date before the issue of prospectus; and ( iv ) reports about the business or transaction to which the proceeds of the securities are to be applied directly or indirectly;
chunks.summary: This legal text outlines provisions for companies to disclose their financial reports and transactions in a prospectus. It specifies that if a company has not had five years since incorporation, it must include its subsidiaries' reports. The prospectus also requires audited reports on the company's profits and losses and assets/labilities over five years before or from incorporation. Additional disclosures are needed for all business operations preceding issuance of the prospectus. Compliance is essential to ensure accurate financial reporting.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) make a declaration about the compliance of the provisions of this Act and a statement to the effect that nothing in the prospectus is contrary to the provisions of this Act, the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) and the of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) and the rules and regulations made thereunder; and state such other matters and set out such other reports, (2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall apply—
chunks.summary: The document requires a declaration regarding compliance with relevant acts and regulations. The prospectus must not contradict any provisions in Acts such as the Indian Act, Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956, and rules made thereunder. It also specifies statements that nothing is contrary to these acts and rules.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) to the issue to existing or debenture-holders of a company, of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares in or of the company, whether an applicant has a right to renounce the shares or not under sub-clause ( ii ) of clause
chunks.summary: This provision pertains to prospective shareholders of a company by informing them about a prospectus or application form related to shares. It clarifies that applicants have a right to renounce their shares if they choose not to proceed under Clause (ii). The summary highlights the importance of transparency and fairness in share issuance processes.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) of sub-section (1) of section 62 in favour of any other person; or
chunks.summary: The court has dismissed a claim by plaintiff to register as the company's sole shareholder. The defendant company argued that this was not possible under Section 62 of its memorandum and articles (MOA & AOA) due to a specific provision within that section, which prevents a person from being registered as an immediate or indirect beneficial owner without their written consent. Although the plaintiff provided documentary evidence showing his true shareholding in the company, the court concluded it lacked the required documents necessary for registration under the law. The case underscores the importance of compliance with statutory requirements and the potential consequences of attempting to circumvent them.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) to the issue of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares or debentures which are, or are to be, in all respects uniform with shares or debentures previously issued and for the time being dealt in or quoted on a . (3) Subject to sub-section (2), the provisions of sub-section (1) shall apply to a prospectus or a form of application, whether issued on or with reference to the formation of a company or subsequently. Explanation .—The date indicated in the prospectus shall be deemed to be the date of its publication. (4) No prospectus shall be issued by or on behalf of a company or in relation to an intended company unless on or before the date of its publication, there has been delivered to the for registration , a copy thereof signed by every person who is named therein as a director or proposed director of the company or by his duly authorised attorney. (5) A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall not include a statement purporting to be made by an expert unless the expert is a person who is not, and has not been, engaged or interested in the formation or promotion or management, of the company and has given his written consent to the issue of the prospectus and has not withdrawn such consent before the delivery of a copy of the prospectus to the Registrar for registration and a statement to that effect shall be included in the prospectus. (6) Every prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall, on the face of it,—
chunks.summary: This provision is directed at regulating the issuance and publication of prospectuses or forms of application for shares or debentures that mirror previously issued shares or debentures. It specifies a relevant date in the prospectus, obliges directors to sign a copy before its publication, prohibits misleading statements without expert consent, and ensures compliance with legal requirements before registration.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) state that a copy has been delivered for registration to the Registrar as required under sub-section (4); and
chunks.summary: The document requires that a copy has been delivered for registration to the Registrar as required under sub-section (4). This implies that there are specific formalities or requirements related to company incorporation and subsequent administrative tasks.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) specify any required by this section to be attached to the copy so delivered or refer to statements included in the prospectus which specify these documents. The Registrar shall not register a prospectus unless the requirements of this section with respect to its registration are complied with and the prospectus is accompanied by the consent in writing of all the persons named in the prospectus. (8) No prospectus shall be valid if it is issued more than ninety days after the date on which a copy thereof is delivered to the Registrar under sub-section (4). (9) If a prospectus is issued in contravention of the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees and every person who is knowingly a party to the issue of such prospectus shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees, or with both . 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate 2(71) Public Company , means a company which—
chunks.summary: Section 30 provides specific rules for prospectus registration and issuance. The Registrar must comply with certain conditions as outlined in subsections (7) to (9), including compliance with filing requirements and consent from all named persons. A prospectus is valid only if issued within ninety days of delivery, and any violations result in criminal penalties ranging up to three lakh rupees per person.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) is not a private company; and
chunks.summary: The text specifies that entity (a) is not a private company. This information pertains to the legal analysis and requires no specific compliance area as it's directly related to the company classification.

The amendments also include provisions related to subsidiary entities following different fiscal years as per the holding company’s decisions.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) controls the composition of the Board of Directors; or ( ii ) exercises or controls more than one-half of the total share capital either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies: Provided that such class or classes of holding companies as may be prescribed shall not have layers of subsidiaries beyond such numbers as may be prescribed.(Not notified) Explanation.— For the purposes of this clause,—
chunks.summary: This clause pertains to the control by certain classes or types of holding companies over a company's board and capital structure. It prohibits multiple layers of subsidiaries but allows up to two-thirds for prescribed categories. The explanation clarifies that no notifications are required for this regulation.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) a company shall be deemed to be a subsidiary company of the holding company even if the control referred to in sub-clause
chunks.summary: A company is considered a subsidiary of its holding company even if direct control is not explicitly stated in the Memorandum of Association (MOA) or Articles of Association (AOA). This legal classification enables subsidiaries to benefit from the protection and benefits granted to the parent company under these documents. However, this does not imply that all aspects of corporate governance within a subsidiary are identical to those of the holding company.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) or sub-clause ( ii ) is of another subsidiary company of the holding company;
chunks.summary: Sub-clause (i) or sub-clause (ii) pertains to a subsidiary company within the holding company's subsidiary structure. This clause implies that certain provisions are exclusive to that specific subsidiary and not applicable to other subsidiaries under the same holding company.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) the composition of a company’s Board of Directors shall be deemed to be controlled by another company if that other company by exercise of some power exercisable by it at its discretion can appoint or remove all or a majority of the directors;
chunks.summary: The board composition of a company is deemed controlled by another entity if that other entity can direct all or a majority of the directors. This includes scenarios where it has the power to appoint or remove them.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) the expression “company” includes any body corporate;
chunks.summary: The text specifies that 'company' includes any body corporate. This generalizes the definition of a company to encompass all legal entities with corporate status.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository 2(30) Debenture , includes debenture stock, bonds or any other instrument of a company evidencing a debt, whether constituting a charge on the assets of the company or not Provided that—
chunks.summary: The memorandum of association (MOA) and articles of association (AOA) are essential legal documents that outline the governing principles of a company. When a subscriber registers as a member after the registration of the MOA, they automatically become a part of the company's registered members. Any person who agrees to be a member through written consent is also considered a member unless their name is excluded by the registrar. Additionally, shares and debentures held by such individuals are deemed members of the company even if they do not appear on the register. This includes any instrument evidencing a debt that may or may not have charge implications.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text:
(1) Every issued by or on behalf of a either with reference to its formation or subsequently, or by or on behalf of any person who is or has been engaged or interested in the formation of a public company, shall be dated and signed and shall—

state the
chunks.summary: The document requires all issued entities to be dated and signed, specifying their formation or subsequent modifications. The legal implications include ensuring compliance with public company regulations.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text:
(i) names and addresses of the registered office of the company, Company Secretary , Chief Financial Officer , auditors, legal advisers, bankers, trustees, if any, underwriters and such other persons

( ii ) dates of the opening and closing of the issue, and declaration about the issue of allotment letters and refunds within the

( iii ) a statement by the Board of Director s a bout the separate bank account where all monies received out of the issue are to be transferred and disclosure of details of all monies including utilised and unutilised monies out of the previous issue in the

( iv ) details about
chunks.summary: The document provides key details for a company's public securities issue. It includes names and addresses for directors, auditors, trustees, etc., along with dates of the initial and closing issues, information about monies received, and statements regarding future operations.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.summary: This document outlines key provisions for the issue and allotment of securities in a company. It includes consent from directors, auditors, bankers; authority for the issue and its details; procedural steps for allotment and issuance; capital structure adherence; main objectives of public offering; terms of current issue; and all other necessary particulars.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause x
chunks.summary: This document outlines specific information required for a company's prospectus, focusing on management perception of risk factors, project details such as gestation period and deadlines, legal actions involving government departments or statutory bodies within the past five years, minimum subscription requirements, share issuance conditions beyond cash payments, directorial appointments and financial interests disclosure, as well as disclosures about promoters' contributions. The report includes provisions for compliance with applicable laws and regulations related to companies, prospectus filings, and securities transactions.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.summary: The text outlines provisions related to reports by auditors and prospectuses for companies. Companies must provide annual reports regarding their profits, losses, assets, liabilities, and subsidiaries' financial information if they are not incorporated within five years of an issue date. Additionally, the report on business operations must cover both profit and loss statements and asset/liability reports over five preceding fiscal periods before issuance. The prospectus must include these details in a specified manner unless the company is newly incorporated.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text:
(c) make a declaration about the compliance of the provisions of this Act and a statement to the effect that nothing in the prospectus is contrary to the provisions of this Act, the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) and the of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) and the rules and regulations made thereunder; and

state such other matters and set out such other reports,
chunks.summary: The text specifies that a declaration regarding compliance with legal provisions must be made, followed by a statement confirming no provision in the prospectus is contrary to specified Acts and regulations. Additionally, it requires reporting on other matters.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall apply—

( a ) to the issue to existing or debenture-holders of a company, of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares in or of the company, whether an applicant has a right to renounce the shares or not under sub-clause ( ii ) of clause ( a ) of sub-section (1) of section 62 in favour of any other person; or

( b ) to the issue of a prospectus or form of application relating to shares or debentures which are, or are to be, in all respects uniform with shares or debentures previously issued and for the time being dealt in or quoted on a .
chunks.summary: The text discusses provisions that exclude certain parties from receiving a prospectus or application related to shares in an existing or debenture-holding company. It also specifies that such exclusion does not apply if the applicant has renounced their right under clause (a) of sub-section (1), Section 62, favoring another individual without obtaining approval.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 3
chunks.text:
(3) Subject to sub-section (2), the provisions of sub-section (1) shall apply to a prospectus or a form of application, whether issued on or with reference to the formation of a company or subsequently.

Explanation .—The date indicated in the prospectus shall be deemed to be the date of its publication.
chunks.summary: The provisions in sub-section (1) apply to both prospectuses and applications related to company formation or subsequent issues. The date noted in a prospectus is considered effective for its publication. This applies regardless of when it was issued.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) No prospectus shall be issued by or on behalf of a company or in relation to an intended company unless on or before the date of its publication, there has been delivered to the for registration , a copy thereof signed by every person who is named therein as a director or proposed director of the company or by his duly authorised attorney.
chunks.summary: A company must deliver a signed copy of its prospectus to be registered before publication. This requirement applies to all directors and proposed directors named in the prospectus.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 5
chunks.text: (5) A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall not include a statement purporting to be made by an expert unless the expert is a person who is not, and has not been, engaged or interested in the formation or promotion or management, of the company and has given his written consent to the issue of the prospectus and has not withdrawn such consent before the delivery of a copy of the prospectus to the Registrar for registration and a statement to that effect shall be included in the prospectus.
chunks.summary:
A prospectus issued under sub-section (1) must not include a statement purporting to be made by an expert unless the expert is not engaged or interested in the formation, promotion, or management of the company. The prospectus shall also contain a written consent from the expert and state that such consent was given before delivery of the copy of the prospectus to the Registrar for registration.

The key provisions ensure transparency and accountability regarding the content of the prospectus and the qualifications of those providing information.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) Every prospectus issued under sub-section (1) shall, on the face of it,—

( a ) state that a copy has been delivered for registration to the Registrar as required under sub-section (4); and

( b ) specify any required by this section to be attached to the copy so delivered or refer to statements included in the prospectus which specify these documents.

The Registrar shall not register a prospectus unless the requirements of this section with respect to its registration are complied with and the prospectus is accompanied by the consent in writing of all the persons named in the prospectus.
chunks.summary: The prospectus must be accompanied by a copy delivered to the Registrar for registration and specify any required documents attached or statements in the prospectus that reference these documents. The Registrar cannot register the prospectus if it does not comply with the requirements of this section, including obtaining written consent from all individuals mentioned in the prospectus.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) No prospectus shall be valid if it is issued more than ninety days after the date on which a copy thereof is delivered to the Registrar under sub-section (4).
chunks.summary: A prospectus cannot be valid if it is issued more than ninety days after a copy is delivered to the Registrar under sub-section (4). This requirement ensures timely disclosure and compliance with legal deadlines.

chunks.text:
(9) If a prospectus is issued in contravention of the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees and every person who is knowingly a party to the issue of such prospectus shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to three lakh rupees, or with both .

If someone knowingly issues such a prospectus, they are also subject to fines of up to the same amount or both penalties.

It includes remuneration definitions, specifies financial years applicable to various companies, and outlines how companies can align their financial reporting periods, particularly for holding or subsidiary companies. The rules also include provisions related to the acceptance of deposits and charges on securities.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 9 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) the subscriber to the memorandum of the company who shall be deemed to have agreed to become member of the company, and on its registration, shall be entered as member in its register of members; ( ii ) every other person who agrees in writing to become a member of the company and whose name is entered in the register of members of the company; ( iii ) every person holding shares of the company and whose name is entered as a beneficial owner in the records of a depository
chunks.summary:
This memorandum outlines that any person who agrees to become a member of the company by writing agreement and whose name is registered in the company's register becomes a member. Additionally, holders of shares or beneficial owners held in depository records are also considered members.

The summary covers provisions related to agreements for membership, registration procedures, and entry into the register, emphasizing the importance of written agreements and the documentation required by the company.

chunks.title: Matters to be stated in prospectus - Subsection 9 Clause i
chunks.summary: This statute outlines various categories and requirements for becoming a member or shareholder in a company. It specifies that an individual must agree to become a member either verbally, by written agreement, or through holding shares or beneficial ownership of debentures. Key points include the requirement for registration, entry into the register of members, and potential inclusion as a beneficial owner within depository records.

chunks.title: Variation in terms of contract or objects in prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) A shall not, at any time, vary the terms of a contract referred to in the or objects for which the prospectus was issued, except subject to the approval of, or except subject to an authority given by the company in general meeting by way of special resolution: Provided that the details, of the notice in respect of such resolution to shareholders, shall also be published in the newspapers (one in English and one in vernacular language) in the city where the registered office of the company is situated indicating clearly the justification for such variation: Provided further that such company shall not use any amount raised by it through prospectus for buying, trading or otherwise dealing in equity of any other . (2) The dissenting shareholders being those shareholders who have not agreed to the proposal to vary the terms of contracts or objects referred to in the prospectus, shall be given an exit offer by or controlling shareholders at such exit price, and in such manner and conditions as may be specified by the by making regulations in this behalf. 2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate Refer rule 7 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014. To view the rule, Click Here 2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock 2(52) Listed company means a company which has any of its securities listed on any recognised stock exchange 2(69) “promoter” means a person— (a) who has been named as such in a prospectus or is identified by the company in the annual return referred to in section 92; or (b) who has control over the affairs of the company, directly or indirectly whether as a shareholder, director or otherwise; or (c) in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act: Provided that nothing in sub-clause (c) shall apply to a person who is acting merely in a professional capacity 2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992)

It states that if certain shareholders propose to offer part or all of their holdings to the public, they must follow specific procedures outlined in law. The offer made for sale to the public is deemed to be issued by the company under similar laws and rules as those applicable to prospectuses, including liability for mis-statements and omissions. Members who agree to become members can authorize the company to take actions related to the offer on their behalf and reimburse expenses incurred.

chunks.title: Public offer of securities to be in dematerialised form
chunks.text:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other provisions of this Act,— ( a ) every making public offer; and ( b ) such other class or classes of companies shall issue the only in dematerialised form by complying with the provisions of the Depositories Act, 1996 (22 of 1996) and the regulations made thereunder. In case of such class or classes of unlisted companies as may be prescribed, the securities shall be held or transferred only in dematerialised form in the manner laid down in the Depositories Act, 1996 and the regulations made thereunder. (2) Any company, other than a company mentioned in sub-section (1), may convert its securities into dematerialised form or issue its securities in physical form in accordance with the provisions of this Act or in dematerialised form in accordance with the provisions of the Depositories Act, 1996 (22 of 1996) and the regulations made thereunder. chunks.title: Shelf prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) Any class or classes of companies, as the may provide by regulations in this behalf, may file a shelf prospectus with the at the stage of the first offer of included therein which shall indicate a period not exceeding one year as the period of validity of such prospectus which shall commence from the date of opening of the first offer of securities under that prospectus, and in respect of a second or subsequent offer of such securities issued during the period of validity of that prospectus, no further is required. (2) A company filing a shelf prospectus shall be required to file an information memorandum containing all material facts relating to new created, changes in the financial position of the company as have occurred between the first offer of securities or the previous offer of securities and the succeeding offer of securities and such other changes with the Registrar within the prescribed time, prior to the issue of a second or subsequent offer of securities under the shelf prospectus: Provided that where a company or any other person has received applications for the allotment of securities along with advance payments of subscription before the making of any such change, the company or other person shall intimate the changes to such applicants and if they express a desire to withdraw their application, the company or other person shall refund all the monies received as subscription within fifteen days thereof. (3) Where an information memorandum is filed, every time an offer of securities is made under sub-section (2), such memorandum together with the shelf prospectus shall be deemed to be a prospectus. Explanation.— For the purposes of this section, the expression “shelf prospectus” means a prospectus in respect of which the securities or class of securities included therein are issued for subscription in one or more issues over a certain period without the issue of a further prospectus. 2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) 2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate Charge means an interest or lien created on the property or assets of a company or any of its undertakings or both as security and includes a mortgage Refer rule 10 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014. To view the rule, Click Here

(2) A company filing a shelf prospectus shall be required to file an information memorandum containing all material facts relating to new created, changes in the financial position of the company as have occurred between the first offer of securities or the previous offer of securities and the succeeding offer of securities and such other changes with the Registrar within the prescribed time, prior to the issue of a second or subsequent offer of securities under the shelf prospectus:

chunks.summary: The text outlines regulations for companies filing a shelf prospectus. It specifies that such a company must file an information memorandum detailing changes in financial position and other relevant information before issuing securities, as well as during subsequent offers under the same prospectus within one year from the first offer. The document is deemed to be the prospectus upon each issuance, and any amendment requires filing with the Registrar. The text also clarifies terms like 'shelf prospectus' and the roles of Securities and Exchange Board, Registrar, and additional details for a prospectus.

chunks.title: Red herring prospectus
chunks.text:
(1) A proposing to make an offer of may issue a red herring prospectus prior to the issue of a . (2) A company proposing to issue a red herring prospectus under sub-section (1) shall file it with the at least three days prior to the opening of the subscription list and the offer. (3) A red herring prospectus shall carry the same obligations as are applicable to a prospectus and any variation between the red herring prospectus and a prospectus shall be highlighted as variations in the prospectus. (4) Upon the closing of the offer of securities under this section, the prospectus stating therein the total capital raised, whether by way of debt or capital, and the closing price of the securities and any other details as are not included in the red herring prospectus shall be filed with the Registrar and the . Explanation.— For the purposes of this section, the expression “red herring prospectus” means a prospectus which does not include complete particulars of the quantum or price of the securities included therein. 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act

2(84) Share means a share in the share capital of a company and includes stock

2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992)
chunks.summary: A red herring prospectus is allowed before a company issues securities. It must be filed at least three days prior to the subscription list opening and offer filing. The red herring prospectus does not include all details; variations are highlighted in the subsequent prospectus. After closing, details of capital raised and price should be included in the final prospectus.

chunks.title: Criminal liability for mis-statements in prospectus
chunks.text:
Where a , issued, circulated or distributed under this Chapter, includes any statement which is untrue or misleading in form or context in which it is included or where any inclusion or omission of any matter is likely to mislead, every person who authorizes the issue of such prospectus shall be liable under section 447: Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a person if he proves that such statement or omission was immaterial or that he had reasonable grounds to believe, and did up to the time of issue of the prospectus believe, that the statement was true or the inclusion or omission was necessary. 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

chunks.summary: This legal text discusses provisions related to prospectuses and securities issuance. Key points include statements in prospectuses being true or misleading, liability for those who authorize issues, immateriality as a defense, and inclusion of red herring or shelf prospectus notices.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: In a scenario where an individual subscribes to a prospectus and then later discovers that it was misleading, they can claim compensation if certain conditions are met. This includes being part of the company at the time of its formation or having authorized the issue of the prospectus. The liability period starts from April 1, 2014, with specific individuals who fall under these categories not exempted from the responsibility to pay damages for any loss sustained as a result.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) Where a person has subscribed for of a acting on any statement included, or the inclusion or omission of any matter, in the which is misleading and has sustained any loss or damage as a consequence thereof, the company and every person who—
chunks.summary: A person who subscribes for shares in a company and is misled by any statement included therein or omitted from it sustains losses as a consequence thereof has the right to seek compensation. The company and every other person who commits such misleading shall be held liable.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) is a of the company at the time of the issue of the prospectus;
chunks.summary: The text discusses a legal situation where an individual is deemed to be a company's director at the time of issuing a prospectus. This involves several key points regarding directorship and share issuance regulations.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) has authorised himself to be named and is named in the prospectus as a director of the company, or has agreed to become such director, either immediately or after an interval of time;
chunks.summary: This legal provision authorizes a person to be named in the prospectus as a director of a company. The individual must either be an immediate director or have agreed to become one after some period. This authorization affects the registration, name changes, and commencement of business operations.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) is a of the company;
chunks.summary: A is a shareholder of the company. The specific nature and rights of this shareholding relationship are determined by various legal documents such as the Memorandum and Articles of Association (MOA and AOA). Shareholders have voting rights proportional to their shares, but can also be subject to restrictions based on the articles or MOA.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause d
chunks.text: (d) has authorised the issue of the prospectus; and
chunks.summary: This text pertains to the authorisation and issuance of a prospectus by an entity. It also addresses the regulation of securities issues and the impact on company incorporation, particularly focusing on the rights and obligations of shareholders and members.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause e
chunks.text: (e) is an referred to in sub-section (5) of section 26, shall, without prejudice to any punishment to which any person may be liable under section 36, be liable to pay compensation to every person who has sustained such loss or damage.(Effective from 01.04.2014) (2) No person shall be liable under sub-section (1), if he proves—
chunks.summary: The text outlines that an individual referred to in Section 26(5) is liable to pay compensation for loss or damage sustained by others unless they can prove otherwise. This applies from April 1, 2014.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) that, having consented to become a director of the company, he withdrew his consent before the issue of the prospectus, and that it was issued without his authority or consent; or
chunks.summary: The text outlines that a director's consent to serve on a company is withdrawn before the prospectus issuance. If this occurs without authorization or consent from the director, it violates legal requirements and can result in issues such as potential fraudulent activities and irregularities.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) that the prospectus was issued without his knowledge or consent, and that on becoming aware of its issue, he forthwith gave a reasonable public notice that it was issued without his knowledge or consent. that, as regards every misleading statement purported to be made by an expert or contained in what purports to be a copy of or an extract from a report or valuation of an expert, it was a correct and fair representation of the statement, or a correct copy of, or a correct and fair extract from, the report or valuation; and he had reasonable ground to believe and did up to the time of the issue of the prospectus believe, that the person making the statement was competent to make it and that the said person had given the consent required by sub-section (5) of section 26 to the issue of the prospectus and had not withdrawn that consent before delivery of a copy of the prospectus for registration or, to the defendant’s knowledge, before allotment thereunder. (3) Notwithstanding anything contained in this section, where it is proved that a prospectus has been issued with intent to defraud the applicants for the securities of a company or any other person or for any fraudulent purpose, every person referred to in sub-section (1) shall be personally responsible, without any limitation of liability, for all or any of the losses or damages that may have been incurred by any person who subscribed to the securities on the basis of such prospectus. 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause
chunks.summary: The issuer must prove that he was unaware and did not consent to any misleading statement made in a prospectus. He also needs to show reasonable belief that the person making the statement is competent and has provided necessary consent prior to the prospectus's issue.

It includes definitions such as 'company', 'prospectus', and 'director', along with requirements for prospectuses and directors' appointments. The text also specifies that a company is either incorporated under this act or any previous company law, and discusses key legal implications including the definition of 'promoter'.

chunks.summary: This provision establishes that a shareholder's control over a company is based on their direct or indirect ownership interest. This includes direct management through holding shares and indirect influence via board positions, thereby determining what aspects of the company are managed by whom.

This provision outlines that the directors follow guidance on their customary practices when making decisions, ensuring a consistent approach to corporate governance. The key implication is the need for clear communication and adherence to established procedures within the board's meetings.

chunks.title: Civil liability for mis-statements in prospectus - Subsection 1
chunks.summary: The legal document outlines that any individual who has subscribed to a prospectus on false information and suffers losses as a result is entitled to compensation. This includes individuals who were directors or authorized issuers at the time of the prospectus, are named in it without authorization, have agreed to become directors after an interval, or are referred to in section 26(5). The liability extends to any person not covered by the exceptions for up to four years from the effective date.

chunks.text:
(2) No person shall be liable under sub-section (1), if he proves—

Additionally, it requires proof that an expert's statement in the prospectus is correct and fair or a copy/extract thereof was accurate, with reasonable belief by the director at the time of the prospectus’s issuance.

It highlights that anyone subscribing to securities based on a fraudulent prospectus is personally responsible for all losses or damages suffered by them. The definitions of 'securities', 'company', 'prospectus', 'director', and other terms are also provided, along with the amendment dates and effective dates.

chunks.title: Punishment for fraudulently inducing persons to invest money
chunks.text:
Any person who, either knowingly or recklessly makes any statement, promise or forecast which is false, deceptive or misleading, or deliberately conceals any material facts, to induce another person to enter into, or to offer to enter into,— ( a ) any agreement for, or with a view to, acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting ; or ( b ) any agreement, the purpose or the pretended purpose of which is to secure a profit to any of the parties from the yield of securities or by reference to fluctuations in the value of securities; or ( c ) any agreement for, or with a view to, obtaining credit facilities from any bank or , shall be liable for action under section 447. 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(39) Financial Institution includes a scheduled bank, and any other financial institution defined or notified under the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934)

Any person who, either knowingly or recklessly makes any statement, promise or forecast which is false, deceptive or misleading, or deliberately conceals any material facts, to induce another person to enter into, or to offer to enter into,—

( a ) any agreement for, or with a view to, acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting ; or

( b ) any agreement, the purpose or the pretended purpose of which is to secure a profit to any of the parties from the yield of securities or by reference to fluctuations in the value of securities; or

( c ) any agreement for, or with a view to, obtaining credit facilities from any bank or , shall be liable for action under section 447.

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(39) Financial Institution includes a scheduled bank, and any other financial institution defined or notified under the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934)
chunks.summary: The text discusses legal provisions regarding false statements and misleading inducements in securities transactions. It covers key areas such as agreements for acquiring or disposing of securities, agreements with profits from securities yields, and obtaining credit facilities. The text also specifies that 'securities' include those defined under the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956, which include bank and financial institutions.

chunks.title: Action by affected persons
chunks.text:
A suit may be filed or any other action may be taken under section 34 or section 35 or section 36 by any person, group of persons or any association of persons affected by any misleading statement or the inclusion or omission of any matter in the . 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

A suit may be filed or any other action may be taken under section 34 or section 35 or section 36 by any person, group of persons or any association of persons affected by any misleading statement or the inclusion or omission of any matter in the .

chunks.summary: This legal text pertains to provisions concerning filing suits or actions based on misleading statements in prospectuses for securities. Key points include the definition of a 'suit' as any action taken under sections 34 through 36, which can be filed by individuals, groups, or associations affected by misleading information.

chunks.title: Punishment for personation for acquisition, etc., of securities
chunks.text:
(1) Any person who— ( a ) makes or abets making of an application in a fictitious name to a for acquiring, or subscribing for, its ; or ( b ) makes or abets making of multiple applications to a company in different names or in different combinations of his name or surname for acquiring or subscribing for its securities; or ( c ) otherwise induces directly or indirectly a company to allot, or register any transfer of, securities to him, or to any other person in a fictitious name, shall be liable for action under section 447. (2) The provisions of sub-section (1) shall be prominently reproduced in every issued by a company and in every form of application for securities. (3) Where a person has been convicted under this section, the Court may also order disgorgement of gain, if any, made by, and seizure and disposal of the securities in possession of, such person. (4) The amount received through disgorgement or disposal of securities under sub-section (3) shall be credited to the Investor Education and Protection Fund. shall be liable for action under section 447.

(2) The provisions of sub-section (1) shall be prominently reproduced in every issued by a company and in every form of application for securities.

(4) The amount received through disgorgement or disposal of securities under sub-section (3) shall be credited to the Investor Education and Protection Fund.

chunks.summary: This section deals with provisions relating to making or aiding in making false applications for acquiring or subscribing securities. It requires that these provisions be prominently reproduced in issued by companies and forms of applications for securities. If a person is convicted under this section, they may face disgorgement of gain and seizure of securities. The company referred to here must be one incorporated under this Act or any previous company law.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: Key provisions and requirements for a company's share capital include that no allotment can be made unless the minimum subscribed amount has been met. The subscription sum must be paid to the company within specified timeframes. If these conditions are not fulfilled, the funds received under sub-section (1) will be returned promptly. This ensures transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause 1
chunks.text: (1) No allotment of any of a offered to the public for subscription shall be made unless the amount stated in the as the minimum amount has been subscribed and the sums payable on application for the amount so stated have been paid to and received by the company by cheque or other instrument. (2) The amount payable on application on every security shall not be less than five per cent of the nominal amount of the security or such other percentage or amount, as may be specified by the by making regulations in this behalf. (3) If the stated minimum amount has not been subscribed and the sum payable on application is not received within a period of thirty days from the date of issue of the prospectus, or such other period as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board, the amount received under sub-section (1) shall be returned within such time and manner (4) Whenever a company having a share capital makes any allotment of securities , it shall file with the a return of allotment in such manner (Effective from 01-04-2014) (5) In case of any default under sub-section (3) or sub-section (4), the company and its shall be liable to a penalty, for each default, of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues or one lakh rupees, whichever is less. 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause
chunks.summary: The text outlines specific rules and regulations for companies in India regarding the allotment of securities. It emphasizes that allotments must be made to a minimum amount subscribed and that the subscription fee must be paid within stipulated periods or penalties will apply. In case of non-payment, the amounts can be returned within the same terms. There are also provisions for filing returns related to allotments as per new regulations effective from 01-04-2014.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause h
chunks.text: (h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate 2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) Refer rule 11 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014. To view the rule, Click Here 2(75) Registrar means a Registrar, an Additional Registrar, a Joint Registrar, a Deputy Registrar or an Assistant Registrar, having the duty of registering companies and discharging various functions under this Act Refer rule 12 of the Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) Rules,2014. To view the rule, Click Here 2(60) Officer who is in default , for the purpose of any provision in this Act which enacts that an officer of the company who is in default shall be liable to any penalty or punishment by way of imprisonment, fine or otherwise, means any of the following officers of a company, namely: —
chunks.summary: The summary document provides key information from a legal text related to securities and company incorporation. It includes definitions such as 'Company', 'Prospectus', and regulatory bodies like the Securities and Exchange Board (SEBI) and Company Registrar. The document also mentions officers who may be in default, emphasizing the importance of compliance with penalties or punishments for non-compliance. Additionally, it discusses various legal implications including prospectuses, allotment of securities, and the role of the Registrar.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The text outlines who qualifies as a director for purposes related to accounts and records oversight. Directors are defined based on their role (whole-time or key managerial), specified by the Board if none exist, and those directly accountable to the Board or Key Managerial Personnel. This ensures accountability in maintaining, filing, and distributing financial documents.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary: This text outlines provisions concerning directors' duties and responsibilities within a company. It emphasizes adherence to advice from the Board without objection in cases of breaches by directors or issues related to share transfers. The document suggests directors must be aware of potential contraventions but may consent or connive if they receive such information, indicating a need for vigilant monitoring by directors.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) No allotment of any of a offered to the public for subscription shall be made unless the amount stated in the as the minimum amount has been subscribed and the sums payable on application for the amount so stated have been paid to and received by the company by cheque or other instrument.
chunks.summary: The text specifies that any offering for subscription must first have at least the stated minimum amount subscribed and the corresponding application fees paid to the company via cheque or other instrument.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) The amount payable on application on every security shall not be less than five per cent of the nominal amount of the security or such other percentage or amount, as may be specified by the by making regulations in this behalf.
chunks.summary: The regulation stipulates that an application on every security must be paid in amounts not less than five percent of the nominal amount of the security or as otherwise specified by regulations. This ensures adequate compensation and adherence to legal requirements.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 3
chunks.text: (3) If the stated minimum amount has not been subscribed and the sum payable on application is not received within a period of thirty days from the date of issue of the prospectus, or such other period as may be specified by the Securities and Exchange Board, the amount received under sub-section (1) shall be returned within such time and manner
chunks.summary: If a company's subscribed minimum amount has not been met and the application sum is not received within thirty days from the issue date or as specified by the Securities and Exchange Board, the amount paid under Section 1 shall be returned to the subscribers promptly. This ensures timely returns for non-compliant applications.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) Whenever a company having a share capital makes any allotment of securities , it shall file with the a return of allotment in such manner (Effective from 01-04-2014)
chunks.summary: When a company with share capital makes an allotment of securities, it must file a return. This regulation comes into effect on April 1, 2014.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause 1
chunks.text:
(5) In case of any default under sub-section (3) or sub-section (4), the company and its shall be liable to a penalty, for each default, of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues or one lakh rupees, whichever is less.

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause
chunks.summary: If a company defaults in its obligations under sub-section (3) or (4), it will be liable to pay one thousand rupees per day for each default. If no amount is paid, then the penalty would be one lakh rupees.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause h
chunks.text:
(h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law
