2(60) Officer who is in default , for the purpose of any provision in this Act which enacts that an officer of the company who is in default shall be liable to any penalty or punishment by way of imprisonment, fine or otherwise, means any of the following officers of a company, namely: —
chunks.summary: The document discusses key provisions related to securities contracts regulation. It mentions that 'Company' refers to a company incorporated under this Act or any previous company law and includes certain types of documents like prospectuses for public offerings. The Securities and Exchange Board, defined by section 2(82), plays a significant role in the industry oversight. The rules mentioned pertain to registration duties for companies and the issuance of securities.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.text: (i) whole-time director; ( ii ) key managerial personnel; ( iii ) where there is no key managerial personnel, such director or directors as specified by the Board in this behalf and who has or have given his or their consent in writing to the Board to such specification, or all the directors, if no director is so specified; ( iv ) any person who, under the immediate authority of the Board or any key managerial personnel, is charged with any responsibility including maintenance, filing or distribution of accounts or records, authorises, actively participates in, knowingly permits, or knowingly fails to take active steps to prevent, any default;
chunks.summary: The text outlines criteria for key individuals in a company's management and governance. It specifies who qualifies as a whole-time director, key managerial personnel, or where there is no such personnel, identifies alternative directors who must consent to their selection by the Board, and defines responsibilities involving direct involvement in corporate activities.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.text: (v) any person in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act, other than a person who gives advice to the Board in a professional capacity; ( vi ) every director, in respect of a contravention of any of the provisions of this Act, who is aware of such contravention by virtue of the receipt by him of any proceedings of the Board or participation in such proceedings without objecting to the same, or where such contravention had taken place with his consent or connivance; ( vii ) in respect of the issue or transfer of any shares of a company, the share transfer agents, registrars and merchant bankers to the issue or transfer
chunks.summary: This provision addresses various directors' responsibilities regarding company issues and transactions. Directors must act in accordance with Board advice or follow professional recommendations from individuals they are accustomed to acting under. In case of contraventions of Act provisions, directors who observe proceedings without objection or knowingly participate without objection may be held accountable. For share issuance and transfers, share transfer agents and registrars also bear compliance responsibilities.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause i
chunks.summary: This legal text outlines the role and responsibilities of directors in a company. It specifies that key managerial personnel are essential but does not mandate their inclusion if no such personnel exist. The definition includes those who have given written consent to specific directorship or all directors, particularly focusing on individuals with authority over financial duties.

chunks.title: Allotment of securities by company - Subsection 5 Clause v
chunks.summary: The text outlines provisions related to directors' obligations and actions in a company. It includes sections on advice given by others (v), failure to object or consent to violations (vi), and issues with share transfers (vii). These clauses emphasize the importance of complying with board instructions, objecting to breaches, and ensuring proper documentation practices.

chunks.title: Securities to be dealt with in stock exchanges
chunks.text:
(1) Every making public offer shall, before making such offer, make an application to one or more or exchanges and obtain permission for the to be dealt with in such stock exchange or exchanges. (2) Where a states that an application under sub-section (1) has been made, such prospectus shall also state the name or names of the stock exchange in which the securities shall be dealt with. (3) All monies received on application from the public for subscription to the securities shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than— ( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities where the securities have been permitted to be dealt with in the stock exchange or stock exchanges specified in the prospectus; or ( b ) for the repayment of monies within the time specified by the , received from applicants in pursuance of the prospectus, where the company is for any other reason unable to allot securities. (4) Any condition purporting to require or bind any applicant for securities to waive compliance with any of the requirements of this section shall be void. (5) If a default is made in complying with the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with a fine which shall not be less than five lakh rupees but which may extend to fifty lakh rupees and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to t hree lakh rupees, or with both . (6) A company may pay commission to any person in connection with the subscription to its securities subject to such conditions (Effective from 01-04-2014) 2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law 2(73) Recognised stock exchange means a recognised stock exchange as defined in clause( f ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) 2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate 2(80) Scheduled bank means the scheduled bank as defined in clause (e) of section 2 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934) 2(82) Securities and Exchange Board means the Securities and Exchange Board of India established under section 3 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) 2(59) Officer includes any director, manager or key managerial personnel or any person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the Board of Directors or any one or more of the directors is or are accustomed to act Omitted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2020 dated 28.09.2020 with effect from 21.12.2020. (1) Every making public offer shall, before making such offer, make an application to one or more or exchanges and obtain permission for the to be dealt with in such stock exchange or exchanges.

(2) Where a states that an application under sub-section (1) has been made, such prospectus shall also state the name or names of the stock exchange in which the securities shall be dealt with.

(3) All monies received on application from the public for subscription to the securities shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities where the securities have been permitted to be dealt with in the stock exchange or stock exchanges specified in the prospectus; or

( b ) for the repayment of monies within the time specified by the , received from applicants in pursuance of the prospectus, where the company is for any other reason unable to allot securities.

(4) Any condition purporting to require or bind any applicant for securities to waive compliance with any of the requirements of this section shall be void.

(5) If a default is made in complying with the provisions of this section, the company shall be punishable with a fine which shall not be less than five lakh rupees but which may extend to fifty lakh rupees and every of the company who is in default shall be punishable with fine which shall not be less than fifty thousand rupees but which may extend to t hree lakh rupees, or with both .

(6) A company may pay commission to any person in connection with the subscription to its securities subject to such conditions (Effective from 01-04-2014)

2(20) Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law

2(73) Recognised stock exchange means a recognised stock exchange as defined in clause( f ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause ( h ) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

2(70) Prospectus means any document described or issued as a prospectus and includes a red herring prospectus referred to in section 32 or shelf prospectus referred to in section 31 or any notice, circular, advertisement or other document inviting offers from the public for the subscription or purchase of any securities of a body corporate

2(80) Scheduled bank means the scheduled bank as defined in clause (e) of section 2 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (2 of 1934)

chunks.summary: The document outlines several key provisions and requirements regarding making public offers. It specifies that before a public offering is made, an application must be submitted to one or more stock exchanges for approval, including details on where securities will be dealt with. Money received from subscribers must be kept in a separate bank account and used exclusively for adjusting allotments or repaying money owed after the prospectus has been issued. Violations of these provisions can result in fines ranging from five lakhs to fifty lakhs per company and each defaulting person.

The rules governing such issuance are outlined in Companies (Issue of Global Depository Receipts) Rules, 2014 and SEBI's Framework for the Issue of Depository Receipts, dated October 10, 2019, and November 28, 2019. This information is available for viewing on specific links provided.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement
chunks.text: [Parent section - see subsections]
chunks.summary: This regulation governs a private placement offering where securities can be offered to identified persons who meet specific criteria. The company must identify no more than fifty or prescribed higher numbers and comply with certain conditions in each financial year. The offer is made via a private placement form issued to the specified individuals, which must not include any rights of ownership.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 1
chunks.text: (1) A company may, subject to the provisions of this section, make a private placement of .
chunks.summary: A company may engage in a private placement. The text does not provide specific details on its content or implications.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 2
chunks.text: (2) A private placement shall be made only to a select group of persons who have been identified by the Board (herein referred to as “identified persons”), whose number shall not exceed fifty or such higher number as may be prescribed [excluding the qualified institutional buyers and employees of the company being offered securities under a scheme of employees stock option in terms of provisions of clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 62], in a financial year subject to such conditions .
chunks.summary: The document specifies that a private placement can be conducted only to up to fifty identified persons or a higher prescribed number, excluding qualified institutional buyers and company employees under specific conditions. The key provisions cover eligibility criteria, maximum participant limit, identification process, and regulatory compliance.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 3
chunks.text:
(3) A company making private placement shall issue private placement offer and application in such form and manner as may be prescribed to identified persons, whose names and addresses are recorded by the company in such manner :

Provided that the private placement offer and application shall not carry any right of renunciation.

Explanation I.—”private placement” means any offer or invitation to subscribe or issue of securities to a select group of persons by a company (other than by way of public offer) through private placement offer-cum-application, which satisfies the conditions specified in this section.

Explanation II.—”qualified institutional buyer” means the qualified institutional buyer as defined in the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2009, as amended from time to time, made under the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992.

Explanation III.—If a company, listed or unlisted, makes an offer to allot or invites subscription, or allots, or enters into an agreement to allot, securities to more than the prescribed number of persons, whether the payment for the securities has been received or not or whether the company intends to list its securities or not on any in or outside India, the same shall be deemed to be an offer to the public and shall accordingly be governed by the provisions of Part I of this Chapter.
chunks.summary: A company making a private placement must issue a private placement offer and application to identified persons. The offer is subject to compliance with specified conditions and cannot include rights of renunciation. Qualified institutional buyers are defined as those recognized by certain regulations, and public offerings occur when listed companies make more than the required number of allotments.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 4
chunks.text:
(4) Every identified person willing to subscribe to the private placement issue shall apply in the private placement and application issued to such person alongwith subscription money paid either by cheque or demand draft or other banking channel and not by cash:

Provided that a company shall not utilise monies raised through private placement unless allotment is made and the return of allotment is filed with the Registrar in accordance with sub-section (8).
chunks.summary: The document requires all applicants for a private placement to apply with subscription money either through cheque, demand draft, or other banking channels instead of cash. Companies are prohibited from using monies raised via such methods unless they make allotments and file return documentation as per Section 8.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 5
chunks.text:
(5) No fresh offer or invitation under this section shall be made unless the allotments with respect to any offer or invitation made earlier have been completed or that offer or invitation has been withdrawn or abandoned by the company:

Provided that, subject to the maximum number of identified persons under sub-section (2), a company may, at any time, make more than one issue of securities to such class of identified persons .
chunks.summary: A company may not make fresh offers or invitations for securities without completing previous allotments or withdrawing them. Additionally, a company can issue additional securities to existing classes of identified persons up to the maximum number specified in subsection (2).

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) A company making an offer or invitation under this section shall allot its securities within sixty days from the date of receipt of the application money for such securities and if the company is not able to allot the securities within that period, it shall repay the application money to the subscribers within fifteen days from the expiry of sixty days and if the company fails to repay the application money within the aforesaid period, it shall be liable to repay that money with interest at the rate of twelve per cent. per annum from the expiry of the sixtieth day:

Provided that monies received on application under this section shall be kept in a separate bank account in a scheduled bank and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

(a) for adjustment against allotment of securities; or

(b) for the repayment of monies where the company is unable to allot securities.
chunks.summary: A company making an offer or invitation for the allotment of securities is required to allot its securities within sixty days from receiving application money. If unable to do so, they must repay the application money within fifteen days; failure beyond this period results in liability for repayment with interest at twelve percent per annum until repaid.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 7
chunks.text: (7) No company issuing securities under this section shall release any public advertisements or utilise any media, marketing or distribution channels or agents to inform the public at large about such an issue.
chunks.summary: Securities issuance is prohibited for companies under this section. Companies shall not release public advertisements or utilize media, marketing, distribution channels, or agents to inform the public about any securities issue.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) A company making any allotment of securities under this section, shall file with the Registrar a return of allotment within fifteen days from the date of the allotment in such manner as may be prescribed, including a complete list of all allottees, with their full names, addresses, number of securities allotted and such other relevant information .
chunks.summary: The text specifies that a company must file a return of allotment within fifteen days after making an allotment of securities. This includes listing all allottees with their names, addresses, and details of allotted securities along with necessary information.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) If a company defaults in filing the return of allotment within the period prescribed under sub-section (8), the company, its promoters and directors shall be liable to a penalty for each default of one thousand rupees for each day during which such default continues but not exceeding twenty-five lakh rupees.
chunks.summary: In cases where a company fails to file its return of allotment within the stipulated period under Sub-section (8), it is subject to a penalty for each day defaulting. The total liability is limited to one thousand rupees per day, with an upper limit not exceeding twenty-five lakh rupees.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10
chunks.text: (10) Subject to sub-section (11), if a company makes an offer or accepts monies in contravention of this section, the company, its promoters and directors shall be liable for a penalty which may extend to the amount raised through the private placement or two crore rupees, whichever is lower, and the company shall also refund all monies with interest as specified in sub-section (6) to subscribers within a period of thirty days of the order imposing the penalty.
chunks.summary: If a company makes an offer or accepts monies in contravention of this section, it, its promoters, and directors are liable for penalties up to the amount raised through the private placement (or two crore rupees, whichever is lower) along with refunding subscribers' money with interest. The company must pay these fines within 30 days from the order imposing them.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 11
chunks.text:
(11) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (9) and sub-section (10), any private placement issue not made in compliance of the provisions of sub-section (2) shall be deemed to be a public offer and all the provisions of this Act and the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 shall be applicable.

Without prejudice to the provisions of section 26, may, subject to the provisions of this section, make private placement through issue of a private placement offer letter.
chunks.summary: This provision explicitly states that any private placement issue not compliant with sub-section (2) is deemed a public offer. The Act and Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956, and Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 apply to such issues. Additionally, the section allows for private placements through issuing a private placement offer letter, subject to compliance with this section.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 2
chunks.text:
(2) Subject to sub-section (1), the offer of or invitation to subscribe securities, shall be made to such number of persons not exceeding fifty or such higher number ,(excluding qualified institutional buyers, and employees of the company being offered securities under a scheme of as per provisions of clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 62), in a and on such conditions (including th e of private placement) .

E xplanation I.—If a company, listed or unlisted, makes an offer to allot or invites subscription, or allots, or enters into an agreement to allot, securities to more than the prescribed number of persons whether the payment for the securities has been received or not or whether the company intends to list its securities or not on any in or outside India, the same shall be deemed to be an offer to the public and shall accordingly be governed by the provisions of Part I of this Chapter.

Explanation II.—For the purposes of this section, the expression—

( i ) “qualified institutional buyer” means the “qualified institutional buyer” as defined in the of India (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirments) Regulations, 2009 as amended from time to time.

( ii ) “private placement” means any offer of securities or invitation to subscribe securities to a select group of persons by a company (other than by way of public offer) through issue of a private placement offer letter and which satisfies the conditions specified in this section.

No fresh offer or invitation under this section shall be made unless the allotments with respect to any offer or invitation made earlier have been completed or that offer or invitation has been withdrawn or abandoned by the company .
chunks.summary: An offer to securities may only be made to up to fifty individuals or an additional number as specified. The company must complete allotments for earlier offers or withdrawals before a new offer is allowed.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 4
chunks.text: (4) Any offer or invitation not in compliance with the provisions of this section shall be treated as a public offer and all provisions of this Act, and the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956) and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 (15 of 1992) shall be required to be complied with.
chunks.summary: The provision allows for compliance with specific requirements and regulations. An offer or invitation that does not adhere to these provisions shall be considered a public offer under this Act. This section requires adherence to certain rules and acts as a template for the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956, and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 5
chunks.text: (5) All monies payable towards subscription of securities under this section shall be paid through cheque or demand draft or other banking channels but not by cash.
chunks.summary: This section specifies that all payments towards the subscription of securities under the given section must be made via cheque, demand draft, or through banking channels but not by cash. This is a requirement to ensure secure and documented financial transactions.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 6
chunks.text:
(6) A company making an offer or invitation under this section shall allot its securities within from the date of receipt of the application money for such securities and if the company is not able to allot the securities within that period, it shall repay the application money to the subscribers within fifteen days from the date of completion of and if the company fails to repay the application money within the aforesaid period, it shall be liable to repay that money with interest at the rate of twelve per cent per annum from the expiry of the sixtieth day:

Provided that monies received on application under this section shall be kept in a separate bank account in a and shall not be utilised for any purpose other than—

( a ) for adjustment against allotment of securities; or

( b ) for the repayment of monies where the company is unable to allot securities.

All offers covered under this section shall be made only to such persons whose names are recorded by the company prior to the invitation to subscribe, and that such persons shall receive the offer by name, and that a complete record of such offers shall be kept by the company in such manner and complete information about such offer shall be filed with the within a period of thirty days of circulation of relevant private placement offer letter.
chunks.summary: The company must allot securities within six months after receiving application money. If it cannot do so, it must return the money and interest at 12% per annum. Offers are limited to subscribers named in records before the offer period, with complete details filed with a specified authority.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 8
chunks.text: (8) No company offering securities under this section shall release any public advertisements or utilise any media, marketing or distribution channels or agents to inform the public at large about such an offer.
chunks.summary: This section prohibits any company offering securities from publicly advertising or utilizing media channels to inform the public about such an offer. This is a key provision aimed at maintaining investor confidentiality and preventing market manipulation.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 9
chunks.text: (9) Whenever a company makes any allotment of securities under this section, it shall file with the Registrar a return of allotment in such manner , including the complete list of all security-holders, with their full names, addresses, number of securities allotted and such other relevant information .
chunks.summary: When a company makes an allotment of securities under this section, it must file a return with the Registrar and provide a complete list of all security-holders along with their names, addresses, number of securities allotted, and other relevant information.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause 1
chunks.text:
(10) If a company makes an offer or accepts monies in contravention of this section, the company, its and shall be liable for a penalty which may extend to the amount involved in the offer or invitation or two crore rupees, whichever is higher, and the company shall also refund all monies to subscribers within a period of thirty days of the order imposing the penalty.

Substituted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017 dated 03.01.2018, Effective from 7th August,2018. To view the effective notification Click Here

chunks.summary: Companies are liable for penalties and refunds if they make unsolicited offers or accept deposits in contravention of specific legal provisions. The effective date is August 7, 2018, following a company amendment act, with a penalty cap that can exceed the amount involved or two crore rupees, whichever is higher. Effective from July 3, 2018.

chunks.text:

chunks.summary: The relevant provisions of section 2(73) of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956, which define a recognized stock exchange as per clause 'Recognized Stock Exchange', are outlined in Rules 14 of Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities), specifically for the year 2014. The summary includes clarifications on recognizing such exchanges to ensure compliance with legal regulations.

Substituted vide Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017 dated 03.01.2018. To view the notification, Click Here

For nidhi companies, Section 42 shall not apply, except sub-section (1), explanation (11) to sub-section (2), sub-sections (4), (6), (8), (9) and (10) vide notification no. G.S.R. 465(E) dated 05 June 2015. To view the notification, Click Here

2(81) Securities means the securities as defined in clause
chunks.summary: The legal text specifies several amendments to securities contracts regulation in India. It references specific rules and notifications for substitute provisions, clarifications regarding sections like 42, and changes related to nidhi companies. Key points include substitution of certain rules by Companies (Amendment) Act, 2017, and additional exemptions for nidhi companies based on a notification dated June 5, 2015.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause h
chunks.text:
(h) of section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (42 of 1956)

Refer Rule 14 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014.To view the rule, Click Here

2(37) Employees’ stock option means the option given to the directors, officers or employees of a company or of its holding company or subsidiary company or companies, if any, which gives such directors, officers or employees, the benefit or right to purchase, or to subscribe for, the shares of the company at a future date at a pre-determined price

2(41) Financial Year , in relation to any company or body corporate, means the period ending on the 31st day of March every year, and where it has been incorporated on or after the 1st day of January of a year, the period ending on the 31st day of March of the following year, in respect whereof financial statement of the company or body corporate is made up: Provided that on an application made by a company or body corporate, which is a holding company or a subsidiary of a company incorporated outside India and is required to follow a different financial year for consolidation of its accounts outside India, the Tribunal may, if it is satisfied, allow any period as its financial year, whether or not that period is a year: Provided further that a company or body corporate, existing on the commencement of this Act, shall, within a period of two years from such commencement, align its financial year as per the provisions of this clause Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC public company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required. Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC private company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required.

Provided that on an application made by a company or body corporate, which is a holding company or a subsidiary of a company incorporated outside India and is required to follow a different financial year for consolidation of its accounts outside India, the Tribunal may, if it is satisfied, allow any period as its financial year, whether or not that period is a year:

Provided further that a company or body corporate, existing on the commencement of this Act, shall, within a period of two years from such commencement, align its financial year as per the provisions of this clause

Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC public company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required.

Provided also that in case of a Specified IFSC private company, which is a subsidiary of a foreign company, the financial year of the subsidiary may be same as the financial year of its holding company and approval of the Tribunal shall not be required.

Refer Rule 14 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014 and Form PAS 3 to PAS 5. To view the rule, Click Here

Refer Rule 14 of Companies(Prospectus and allotment of securities) rules,2014.To view the rule, Click Here

2(73) Recognised stock exchange means a recognised stock exchange as defined in clause
chunks.summary: This text outlines the definition of an employee's stock option under Section 2(37) of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956. It specifies that such options can be given to directors, officers, or employees of a company within India, its holding companies, subsidiaries, and foreign entities as long as they follow a specific financial year period from March 31st of one fiscal year to the same date in the following fiscal year unless approved by the Tribunal. Additionally, it provides details on recognizing stock exchanges for prospectuses, allotments, and securities, ensuring compliance with Rule 14 of Companies (Prospectus and Allotment of Securities) rules, 2014.

chunks.summary: The notification exempts two specific companies, IFSC Private and IFSC Public, from certain provisions under section 2 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956. It specifies that these changes apply for a period of ninety days to these entities as defined in GSRs 8(E) and 9(E), dated January 4, 2017.

2(69) “promoter” means a person—
chunks.summary: The text outlines provisions concerning companies and securities, particularly in relation to the definition of 'promoter', clarifications on section 2 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, and specific rules related to prospectus and allotment of securities. It also mentions changes that do not apply to certain types of companies (IFSC Private and IFSC Public) based on GSR 8(E) and GSR 9(E), as well as a link for viewing notifications and rules.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) who has been named as such in a prospectus or is identified by the company in the annual return referred to in section 92; or
chunks.summary:
This provision requires that certain individuals or entities be identified in a prospectus or are explicitly named in an annual return. For these provisions to apply, the company must have been incorporated before October 15, 2019 (this change took effect on November 30, 2019), and the registration of directors must have commenced before this date.

Key points: Companies are required to disclose significant information in their annual returns and prospectuses. This includes naming individuals as beneficial owners or controlling members who can significantly influence company affairs. These disclosures enhance transparency and accountability for companies.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) who has control over the affairs of the company, directly or indirectly whether as a shareholder, director or otherwise; or
chunks.summary: This text describes the authority to control a company's affairs through shareholders, directors, or other means. It includes key provisions such as the right to manage the company and specify how the company will be incorporated, named, and operate its business.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act: Provided that nothing in sub-clause
chunks.summary: The company's board of directors typically follows advice, directions, or instructions provided by its president or CEO regarding certain matters. This includes provisions that are customary and expected in their usual practices.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause c
chunks.text: (c) shall apply to a person who is acting merely in a professional capacity
chunks.summary: This provision applies to a person acting solely in their professional capacity. The legal text specifies that this includes persons engaged as professionals without any personal interest or involvement beyond their job duties.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause a
chunks.text: (a) who has been named as such in a prospectus or is identified by the company in the annual return referred to in section 92; or
chunks.summary: The entity in question must be identified either through a prospectus in the prospectus or as an identifiable company within its annual return. This is crucial for ensuring that all necessary legal documents are adhered to and that compliance with relevant regulations is maintained.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause b
chunks.text: (b) who has control over the affairs of the company, directly or indirectly whether as a shareholder, director or otherwise; or
chunks.summary: The corporation is solely owned by individuals or entities with direct and indirect control over its operations. This ownership includes shareholders, directors, and other significant stakeholders who can affect the company's management without formal approval.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause c
chunks.text:
(c) in accordance with whose advice, directions or instructions the Board of Directors of the company is accustomed to act:

Provided that nothing in sub-clause
chunks.summary: This text outlines a clause that specifies how the Board of Directors acts based on advice received from management. The key provisions concern the source of guidance for director actions and any exceptions to this practice.

chunks.title: Offer or invitation for subscription of securities on private placement - Subsection 10 Clause c
chunks.text:
(c) shall apply to a person who is acting merely in a professional capacity

2(34) Director means a director appointed to the Board of a company
chunks.summary: The provision clarifies that a person acting in a professional capacity may be subject to specific regulations, particularly regarding director duties and responsibilities within a company. This includes appointing directors on the Board, understanding what constitutes a 'Director' under the Company Act, and ensuring compliance with various legal requirements related to company management.
